TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 106 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. 2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.

(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to yesterday's acknowledgment by the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation that $11.7m of Reserve Bank of Australia funds has been misused by dairy manufacturing companies. Will the Minister state categorically that the Murray Goulburn Co-op. Co. Ltd, in which the Minister for Primary Industry is a shareholder, is not one of the companies which have been misusing these funds?

—A number of different forms of irregularity have been uncovered by the Corporation in its examination of this matter. Some relate to the fact that there have been sales of a manufactured product which was subject to financial cover and to delayed repayment of the advances which were due to be made. Another area of difficulty has been that some goods have not been kept in approved stores. One of the conditions for the obtaining of the funds is that the goods must be kept in an approved store, which is something that is approved by the Australian Dairy Corporation. My advice is that the company mentioned by the honourable senator in his question is not involved in the delayed repayment of any advances but the investigations have shown that the company has stored some product on which advances have been made in non-approved stores. So there is a deficiency in that area.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that currently the world steel industry is characterised by a gross over-capacity which is being supported by extensive use of subsidies, export incentives and protection measures-many of a non-tariff nature? Does the recent statement by the Minister for Industry and Commerce that the Australian steel industry is one of the few steel industries in the world open to import competition shed any light on the rising imports of steel and on the announcement that the Tasmanian Electro Metallurgical Co. Pty Ltd plant near Launceston has retrenched 63 employees? Is the steel industry's distinctive position in being so open to import competition an inhibiting factor so far as local employment is concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matters raised by the honourable senator in his question were really dealt with in a public statement by the Minister for Industry and Commerce a few days ago, on 21 May. Sir Phillip Lynch mentioned in that statement that a reference would be sent to the Temporary Assistance Authority covering a range of steel products and that a reference would also be sent to the Industries Assistance Commission covering those products and some additional steel items. In the statement Sir Phillip Lynch pointed out that the world steel industry is a classic example of the problems facing world trade and, indeed, a very good example of why the sort of initiative that the Prime Minister has been pursuing abroad needs to be pursued. But quite clearly, in a situation where the Australian industry is one of the few steel industries in the world which is open to import competition, that does put it in a very difficult competitive position. It is for that reason that the references to the Temporary Assistance Authority and the Industries Assistance Commission have been made. The sorts of factors mentioned by Senator Watson in his question certainly do apply.

ANSWER.PARA: It is, of course, the wish of the Government to maintain a healthy and competitive steel industry in Australia. The reference to the Industries Assistance Commission is an indication of the Government's acknowledgement of the difficulties which the industry faces and the views which have been put to it by the industry. The Temporary Assistance Authority is to report to the Government within 45 days of the date of the receipt of the reference. The Industries Assistance Commission report is to be presented within 12 months of the reference. When those reports are received the Government will, of course, be in a position to consider in detail the problems which Senator Watson has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. In the light of the retrenchments that are currently occurring in the industry, particularly in my State of Tasmania, does not the Minister consider that these time intervals are far too long?

—I do not think there has been any sudden change in the competitive position of Australian steel. I think it is the proper policy of the Government not to make decisions on assistance without reference to those expert bodies which can give it impartial advice, against which it can judge what are the most appropriate decisions to be made. I do not believe that a reference in a shorter time would be likely to give the Temporary Assistance Authority a chance to give the sort of attention to the question which it deserves. I will, however, ask Sir Phillip Lynch to consider whether any shortening of the time might be considered. My judgment would be-I stress that it is no more than an individual judgment, made without having considered the matter in detail-that it would be unlikely that a shorter time would be possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts which surround this matter are facts which, I think, have been disclosed by the Australian Dairy Corporation as they have come to light. The Corporation has recently issued a Press release and I understand it will release further information as its inquiries bring forth further facts. As far as the instant case is concerned, I understand that a routine check by the Corporation gave rise to doubts as to whether one company, the United Milk Products Group in Tasmania, was strictly observing the Corporation's rules governing the use of these funds. Detailed inspection of the company's records by Corporation staff from 19 to 22 April confirmed that the company had sold product but had not repaid loans. Management then decided to undertake spot checks on an additional three companies to ascertain whether the Corporation's rules were being observed. ANSWER.PARA: I do not have information as to the attention which has been given to this matter by the Board, but I will check that and let the honourable senator have a reply as quickly as possible-if possible, during Question Time today. I do not see the relevance of the parallel which Senator Walsh has tried to draw in his question, but I will consider that matter to see whether it needs to receive a further substantive reply.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: APPOINTMENT OF PARLIAMENTARIANS TO EDUCATIONAL BODIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education: How many senators and members of the House of Representatives are currently appointed or elected to the governing councils of universities and colleges of advanced education? Is it more than one-possibly two? Is it true that, whereas 30 years ago it was appropriate and perhaps adequate for State parliamentarians to fill the parliamentary places on such councils, it is now an enormous anomaly that this continues despite the fact that the entire public funding for universities and colleges is derived through the Commonwealth and that the focus for parliamentary debate and decision concerning higher education is now in the Senate and in the House of Representatives? I ask: Will the Minister, through the Australian Education Council and in other ways, promote to State Ministers the mutual advantages for education institutions and for Federal parliamentarians of senators and members being included among those from time to time appointed to these governing councils?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Institutions of higher education in the main are State institutions and are governed by Acts of State parliaments. Those Acts provide for the composition of the governing councils. Sometimes members of State parliaments are included among the members who are appointed by the State governors. I am not aware that many councils contain members of the Federal Parliament among their members. I have recently had cause to look through the calendars of some of the universities and I have noticed there a number of State parliamentarians but I have not noticed any Federal parliamentarians. I can advise Senator Teague that where the Commonwealth Government is directly responsible there is Federal representation. For example the Australian National University has two senators and two members of the House of Representatives on the governing council. I believe that Senator Peter Rae and Senator Georges have represented this chamber on that council. I know that the Minister for Defence has until recent times been a member of the council of the University of New England. I believe he was elected by the other members of that governing council . I was until recently a member of the council of the Cumberland College of Advanced Education.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not able to give any systematic information on the number of senators or members of the House of Representatives who are on different councils. I understand that Senator Martin may be on the council for the University of Queensland. I think if we looked around the country we might be able to find a few Federal representatives. Senator Teague's question is a fair one. The Commonwealth does have a major role in funding universities and colleges. It would not be inappropriate for the Parliament to have a place on these bodies. This would be something which would need to be taken up with my State colleagues . It might be appropriate to take it up at the Australian Education Council to see whether it is possible to have greater representation from the Federal Parliament.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAIRY MANUFACTURING COMPANIES: ALLEGED MISUSE OF FUNDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Are any members of the Australian Dairy Corporation Board also directors of dairy companies which have misused Reserve Bank of Australia funds? If so, who are they? Will they be allowed to remain on the Australian Dairy Corporation Board? I further ask: Will the Minister provide to the Senate a list of all the companies involved in this misuse of funds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to give an immediate answer to the first part of the honourable senator's question but I will check it and let him have a reply. I have advice on the companies which are involved. The Australian Dairy Corporation investigations to date have shown that six companies had products withdrawn from sale, but had not repaid their advances to the Corporation. That is the first class of difficulty which has been uncovered by the Corporation's examination. These companies include Bodalla Co-op. Cheese Society Ltd, New South Wales, for which the amount involved is $305,000. I stress that is not an amount of loss. That is an amount advanced which is recoverable and, in the case of these companies, has been recovered. The other companies and amounts involved are: Colac Dairy Co. Ltd, Victoria, $130,000; Drouin Co-op. Butter Factory Co. Ltd, Victoria, $894,000; Petersville Ltd, New South Wales, $742,000; Unigate Australia Pty Ltd, Victoria, $1.25m; United Milk Tasmania Ltd, Tasmania, $1.7m. The total is $5,021,000.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the Dairy Corporation's investigations so far have shown that four companies have been holding product, on which advances have been made by the Corporation, in non-approved stores. These companies are: Downs Co-op. Dairy Association Ltd, Queensland; Murray Goulburn Co-op. Co. Ltd, Victoria; Nestle Co . (Aust.) Ltd, New South Wales, and Unigate Australia Pty Ltd, Victoria. The amounts involved respectively are $19,000, $1,050,000, $1,100,000 and $3,990,000 . That is a separate category where companies have held product in non-approved stores. It has also been found so far that one company has claimed a loan on ineligible product. That company is Norco Co-op Ltd of New South Wales. The amount involved is $541,000.

To avoid any possibility of misleading the Senate, I should perhaps explain, having mentioned those amounts, that that total of $11.7m which has been found to be due for repayment has all been repaid or is properly accounted for. An amount of $7.74m has been repaid. The balance of $3.99m, which was initially found to be due by Unigate, because it was holding product in non-approved stores, has now been regularised because, as a result of the investigations, the company lodged applications on 20 May and the stores have been approved subsequently. So the advance is now in order. That deficiency was remedied.

While I am on my feet I might pick up a point which was raised by Senator Walsh in an earlier question and which I omitted to cover in my answer. The Minister was first advised of this on Wednesday, 19 May; that is, last Wednesday. That is a point which was raised by Senator Walsh earlier and to which I did not respond .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In the answer of the Minister reference was made to the Colac Dairy Co. of Colac, Victoria. A director of that company is Mr David Burston who is also a director of the Australian Dairy Corporation Board. Will the Minister pursue the information that he has, with a view to giving the Senate a full and comprehensive list of any other persons who hold both positions?

—As I indicated earlier in my answer, I do not have the information which was requested in the first part of Senator Bolkus's question. He has now provided me with what he says is a partial answer to that question. I am not in a position to dispute that. I will check the question that he has raised and get an answer to him as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that, last year, the Australian Federal Police mounted a surveillance operation over several members of the New South Wales Police Force, including former Assistant Commissioner Allen, who were suspected of being involved in the collection of bribery money from illegal gambling operations? Is it also a fact that, as part of that surveillance, the Federal Police became aware of meetings between the then New South Wales Minister for Police, Mr Crabtree, and the New South Wales police who were under surveillance? I ask the Attorney-General whether there is any substance in recent allegations that the New South Wales Government will deal with its own and that further retirements and/or resignations are to be expected. Can the Attorney-General say whether all of these activities and the allegations over the resignation of Mr Allen demonstrate the need for a national crimes commission which will investigate the truth or otherwise of these allegations about criminal activities in high places ? Finally, can the Attorney-General say whether there will be full and proper consultation with the States in setting up such a national crimes commission?

—Before I call the Attorney-General I note that Senator Martyr in his question asked about a member of the New South Wales Parliament. Before the Attorney-General replies, I draw attention to Standing Order 418.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Martyr has asked a number of questions, some of which deal with the operations of the Australian Federal Police. I am not in a position to answer the questions related to the operations of the police. I will refer those aspects of the question to the Minister for Administrative Services to see whether the police are in a position to make available any information on these matters or whether, being matters relating to the operations of the police , they should not be matters for disclosure. However, the other aspects of the question I can refer to in general. Copies of the so-called Allen papers have been handed over to the Australian Federal Police by the New South Wales Government, as requested by the Prime Minister. I understand that those papers are currently being studied by the Australian Federal Police but I have no further information in relation to that examination.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Martyr asked specific questions in relation to the establishment of a national crimes commission. The Government believes that the extent of organised crime-I do not know that it is confined to criminal activity in high places; there is a great deal in very low places as well-that has been revealed in a number of recent inquiries is a matter of very great concern. I am not here pointing the bone at the inquiry into the activities of Mr Allen. I refer also to the extent of organised crime revealed in many other inquiries, such as the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and other royal commissions which are also sitting.

The upshot is that the Government believes that there is sufficient evidence and concern to justify a very close examination of the question of establishing a national crimes commission. As I have said, I believe that it would be desirable that such a commission should be supported by the States as well as the Commonwealth. At this stage, the matter is being developed by officers of my Department, in close consultation with me. A submission will be made shortly to the Government for consideration. At this stage, no decision has been made. However, I emphasise that the matter of the establishment of a national crimes commission calls for joint action and consultation between the Commonwealth and the States and that such consultation will take place.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chipp

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Standing Order 418 , to which you properly drew the attention of the Attorney-General before he answered the question, states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall use offensive words against either House of Parliament or any Member of such House, or of any House of a State Parliament, or against any Statute, unless for the purpose of moving for its repeal, and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

I do not want to make the point that Senator Martyr was disorderly in that regard. One could well argue, I think unassailably, that Senator Martyr did not break the wording of Standing Order 418, but I suggest that either wittingly or unwittingly he came perilously close to breaking the spirit of that Standing Order. If that sort of question is allowed in future it will open up a procedure that could be used by both sides of this chamber to name members of State Houses or other people in a way in which that can then be properly used by the Press in headlines, and could well result in unfair and improper treatment being given to possibly innocent individuals. What I am saying is not necessarily a criticism of the question, but I ask you, Mr Deputy President, because of what I regard as the extreme importance of this matter as one of principle in regard to the procedure of this House, to contemplate it and perhaps make a statement on it, after consulting the Clerks, later in the afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have taken on board Senator Chipp's comments.

—I briefly enter the discussion on the point of order. I quite deliberately did not raise the matter of Standing Order 418 when Senator Martyr asked his question although, as Senator Chipp said, one could probably have done so without being considered unreasonable. I intended to raise this matter after Question Time and to ask you, Mr Deputy President, and the President, when he returns, to consider this matter. I think it is significant that the question, which dealt with the matter of the New South Wales Parliament, was raised by a senator from Western Australia in the absence of the Leader of the Government in the Senate who is from New South Wales and that no honourable senator from New South Wales chose to bring up this matter in this way. There are certainly means of skirting around Standing Order 418 and getting down into the gutter in this way and abusing the privileges and the Standing Orders of this Senate. Therefore , I join in by asking you, Mr Deputy President, and the President to consider the situation although, as I said, I deliberately did not raise it when the question was asked because I thought that probably that was what the honourable senator who asked the question wanted.

—I take on board the comments made by Senator Chipp and Senator Grimes. It will have been observed, of course, that, after Senator Martyr asked the question and before the Attorney-General responded, I drew the Senate's attention to Standing Order 418. I think it can therefore be observed that the Chair had in mind the matter raised by Senator Chipp and Senator Grimes . I shall take advice and mention the matter to the President. I hope to be able to make a statement on the matter in due course.

—My question is addressed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that the Minister for Foreign Affairs has discussed with the British Foreign Secretary any requirements Britain might have should she ask us for assistance of any sort to prosecute the Falkland Islands war? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether any request, or any suggestion of a request, has been made by the British for any Australian assistance? Is it a fact, as comments attributed to Mr Sinclair seem to indicate, that the Australian Government has not ruled out the provision of assistance for Britain in the Falklands?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Minister has had some discussions in Britain. I have not yet had any detailed information with regard to the outline of those discussions. It is a fact that there has been no request from Britain for any assistance in the nature of military personnel or equipment or anything else of that sort. That is the position at present. No request has been received . I am aware of a comment that was made by the Minister for Defence. That was in the context that if any request were received it would be given consideration. But up to this point there has been no formal request. As I say, I have not yet had any detailed outline of the discussions that were held by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As I understand it, they were in the context of the position which I have just mentioned.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it a fact , then, that the Australian Government has not ruled out the provision of assistance for Britain?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is a fact that the Government has not received any formal request and has not given consideration to any request.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the crucial paragraph of the 1977 Gleneagles Agreement which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: they-
That is the Commonwealth Heads of Government--

accepted it as the urgent duty of each of their Governments vigorously to combat the evil of apartheid by withholding any form of support for, and by taking every practical step to discourage contact or competition by, their nationals with sporting organisations, teams or sportsmen from South Africa or from any country where sports are organised on the basis of race, colour or ethnic origin .

Does not Australia, indeed, allow organisation of sports on a basis of race? That was indicated by the recent National Aboriginal Sports Foundation being made an associate member of the Australian Confederation of Sports as indicated in the Aboriginal newsletter No. 105 of 7 May 1982. Will the Minister examine this situation immediately to ensure that Australia is not in conflict with the Gleneagles Agreement?

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty in South Africa is that many of the inequalities there are secured by statute and by administrative action. In this country, on the other hand, the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation operates to build yet another bridge by which participation of people can be increased and their involvement in Australian society advanced. The situation is quite different. I understand Senator Townley's concern that we should not unwittingly be in breach of the Gleneagles Agreement, but I put it to him that the very great differences which exist in our practices and our structure make that very unlikely. The NASF has been funded and operates to increase the opportunities by which Aboriginal people can be involved in sport at all levels in this country. The particular carnivals which the NASF does conduct are designed only with that in mind.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. It is a two-tiered question on whale conservation. Is it true that a fortnight ago the International Whaling Commission again gave Japan a blanket exemption from the cessation of the catching sperm whales? As a postcript to that, can the Minister confirm that it is the view of the Duke of Edinburgh that one of the spin-offs of the fighting in the Falkland Islands is that the Royal Navy has inadvertently depth-charged some whales?

—It is with very great regret that I have to inform Senator Mulvihill that I have neither seen the statement of the Duke of Edinburgh nor had the opportunity to ask him about the matter. But I undertake to try to get some comments on these matters, including whether the Japanese have received a further blanket exemption in relation to the harvesting of sperm whales. I will get answers to both of these questions and get them to Senator Mulvihill as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TASMANIA: FUNDING RECOMMENDATIONS OF COMMONWEALTH GRANTS COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware that a study undertaken at the University of Tasmania showed that Tasmania would lose 4,500 jobs, or 2.7 per cent of its work force, if the Commonwealth Grants Commission funding recommendations for 1982-83 were implemented by the Government? Does this not clearly indicate that Tasmania, which has the highest unemployment in Australia, could not absorb the funding cuts as recommended by the Commission? Has the Commission reviewed its recommendations in the light of Tasmania's extraordinary circumstances and present employment situation?

—I think many honourable senators would have noticed the article in this morning's Australian drawing the attention of all of us to the particular point made by Senator Walters in her question. The article refers to recommendations in last year's Commonwealth Grants Commission report which caused concern not only in Tasmania but also in several other States. As an expression of that particular concern the Commission has been asked by the Government to review its recommendations. I understand that that work is going forward. I can make no further report about that matter at present. As soon as some information is available no doubt it will be discussed with the Premiers.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and refers to a question asked of him by my colleague Senator Foreman on 22 April, when in fact he was Minister for Health. I ask the Minister: In view of the fact that the governments of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia have all found it necessary to increase considerably their hospital fees, what is the Government's intention as to hospital fees in the Australian Capital Territory in light of the fact that the same cost pressures apply in that Territory as apply in those States?

—I will have to ask the Minister for Health what his intentions are in regard to the Australian Capital Territory. The point to be made to Senator Grimes and to other honourable senators is that the Commonwealth has acknowledged throughout this year that it is willing to re-examine, in the light of actual experience, the assumptions it made when it produced the arrangements which commenced on 1 September last. Some States and the Northern Territory certainly have already come to the Commonwealth asking that reviews take place. The Commonwealth stands by the assurance that it will carry out these reviews in the light of experience. I shall obtain for Senator Grimes the Commonwealth's intentions in relation to the Capital Territory Health Commission .

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Baume for answering the question that I was going to ask later in Question Time but I do not believe that his answer had anything to do with the question I asked just now. My question refers to hospital fees in the Australian Capital Territory and the fees charged to patients there. I am afraid that Senator Baume was anticipating the wrong question.

—I thank Senator Grimes. I shall have to obtain information from the Minister as to hospital fees charged to patients in the Australian Capital Territory. That is something on which only he can take a decision or give an indication.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction to the recent board meeting of the Australian National Line at which there was to be discussion about improving services to the Northern Territory. The Government subsidy for services to the Northern Territory is to cease at the end of September this year, and the roll-on roll-off wharf facility will be completed in Darwin early in November. Bearing in mind high freight costs to this more remote part of Australia, can the Minister advise the Senate whether people in the north will benefit from the ANL deliberations and what possible effect they will have on future freight rates? Further, will the Government keep in mind, when making decisions on services to the Northern Territory, the benefits of freight assistance enjoyed by Tasmania even though it is much closer to suppliers?

—It is true that the subsidy referred to by Senator Kilgariff will be ceasing at the end of September. However, the Australian National Line is studying alternative ways of servicing Darwin after September, when the subsidy terminates. A number of options are under consideration. All of those are being discussed with the Northern Territory Government. Those discussions have not yet come to a final conclusion. No doubt these decisions with regard to future services require the fullest possible consultations with the Northern Territory Government and interested persons, and since the matter has a special sensitivity in the Northern Territory no doubt they will be most carefully undertaken. In respect of any further information on the matter and as to the progress of those consultations, I shall need to keep Senator Kilgariff, and the Senate generally, informed from time to time as information becomes available.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to advertisements placed in the Australian Financial Review last week by a well- known tax evader, Dr Peter Clyne, in which he states quite categorically that he will not pay any of the $1.16m demanded of him by the Australian Taxation Office . Why is it that newspapers are allowed to publish such advertisements which encourage tax evasion when they are so clearly against the national interest? Will the Government consider taking appropriate action, such as the imposition of heavy fines, to stop newspapers such as the Australian Financial Review so irresponsibly publishing such advertisements in future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think we would be embarking on a new era of censorship if we were to control the type of paid advertisement that may be placed in the daily Press, as related to Dr Peter Clyne and his activities. I think I am right in saying that it would not be the Commonwealth Government that would have any jurisdiction, in any case, with regard to the newspapers concerned. When we read advertisements of that kind, I think we share the same feeling-that his activities over a number of years have represented a blatant abuse of the income tax system and that those who seek to use his systems to avoid their tax commitments certainly do not have the support of the Australian people. It must be said that the many amendments which have been made in recent years to the Income Tax Assessment Act have enabled the closure of a number of his schemes by the Commissioner of Taxation. I can only hope that in the future when such legislation is brought forward from time to time by the Government it will have the support of all members of the Parliament.
—But, Senator, isn't the advertisement an incitement to break the law?

— I suppose that Mr Peter Clyne would say that he uses his skill as an expert in tax avoidance to prepare schemes for people who are able at least to submit them for assessment by the Commissioner of Taxation. As to the Commonwealth Government taking action to prevent in advance the placement of advertisements of that kind, I rather think it would be outside its jurisdiction to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I think it is appropriate that I ask him this question as he is a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister aware that a young Aborigine, Mr David Anderson, is on a hunger strike because of the attitude of the Labor Government of Victoria towards Aboriginal claims to land rights and related matters? Will the Minister contact the Premier of Victoria to seek his views on the matters raised by this fine young Australian? Will the Minister also speak to the Victorian Minister of Health to ensure that steps are taken to make sure that Mr Anderson is not forced to continue his strike until he has done great harm to his health?
—Mr Deputy President, I wonder whether Senator Bonner could indicate whether he is referring to the Mr David Anderson who was a member of the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee.
—Yes.

—Many of us would know Mr Anderson and the work he has done over a number of years. We would also know that he has had a fairly difficult time over recent years. I am very distressed to hear that he is on a hunger strike. It seems quite reasonable to make Senator Bonner's concerns known to Mr Cain, who is the Minister responsible for Aboriginal affairs in Victoria. The Government, I understand, has given certain undertakings in relation to legislation it hopes to introduce. It may, in fact, be premature for Mr Anderson to be responding in this way at this time. I understand Senator Bonner's concern for Mr Anderson's welfare and undertake to try to make contact with the Victorian Ministers, as he suggests.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given the notoriously appalling record of the South Korean Government in the protection of human rights over a long period-a record which is almost indistinguishable from that of its near northern neighbour-and given the fact, among others, that something over 400 political detainees are still in South Korean gaols, including Mr Kim Dae Jung, who has been the subject of resolutions in this Parliament, how can the Government justify the Prime Minister spending, as has been reported, only five minutes discussing human rights subjects during his day of talks with the South Korean Prime Minister?
—I am not aware of the report referred to by Senator Evans.
—The Melbourne Age, this morning.

—I am sorry, but I did not read the Melbourne Age this morning. I do not even know whether we can accept that the amount of time spent discussing the subject was as reported. I know the Prime Minister indicated that he, quite properly, would raise the subject with the South Korean Government. I will take note of the question and endeavour to obtain more details from the Prime Minister.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to the report of the Australian Sheep Meat Study Mission to the Middle East which was tabled in the Senate last Thursday. I refer also to comments made by Senator Childs during which he claimed that the members of the mission unanimously agreed to recommend the placing of a tax on exported live sheep and that the money received from this tax be used to facilitate the export of sheep meats. Will the Minister ask producer members of that mission whether the imposing of that tax was ever a unanimous decision of that mission? Further, because I cannot find any reference to this matter in the report, does the Minister share my belief that Senator Childs has received his information from Mr O'Toole rather than from the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to speculate on where Senator Childs might get his information. It is a fact that the report of the mission was tabled in the other place earlier this month. The recommendations, which I understand to be unanimous, are a matter of public record. I have recently read those recommendations and to the best of my recollection they contain no recommendation along the lines indicated in the information given by Senator Thomas. In other words, there is no reference to the imposing of a tax on the export of sheep in the form that is suggested. There are recommendations which relate to the promotion of the export of carcass meats. That is a matter on which there was some unanimity of view. That recommendation, along with the other recommendations of the study mission, is under close examination by the Government. I know that the Minister for Primary Industry is expecting to have discussions with the parties to that mission and that he hopes to be able to make a public statement on the matter in the reasonably near future.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot go beyond that, except to assure the Senate that the recommendations are those which have already been published. They do not contain a proposal of the sort which is mentioned. It may well be that there are different views on how some of the commonly agreed objectives might be achieved and financed, but that is a quite separate matter and the sort of matter which no doubt Mr Nixon will be taking up with the parties to the mission. The really important thing is that a diverse group representing government, growers and the unions involved has been able to come forward with a group of common recommendations in an area which is important to Australia's trade, to the growers and to the trade unions involved. I think we should welcome that. There should be a common view. We hope that, flowing from those recommendations, Mr Nixon will be able to produce useful, positive actions by the Government which will have the support of all parties to the industry. It is an industry which has not benefited by disputation in the past. This common effort, which I think is a really positive achievement, is something we should try to capitalise and build on.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. At present the sales tax imposed on materials for vessels built for the tourist trade is between 17 1/2 per cent and 20 per cent. I refer particularly to paddle steamers that carry tourists on the River Murray in South Australia. Will the Minister use her good offices to see whether the Government will greatly reduce the sales tax on materials used in these vessels which provide employment in building and outfitting and which promote tourism and further employment? As many similar projects are in danger of being cancelled because of the added costs of materials plus the sales tax, will the Minister treat this matter as one of urgency when budgetary considerations are under way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob raised a matter of policy when he referred to discussions that can be undertaken in the context of the forthcoming Budget. I will draw the Treasurer's attention to the matter that he has raised with regard to the level of sales tax and the difficulties that this causes for those who are seeking to find employment in the industries that he has mentioned . As it is a matter of policy I am not able to make any comment on it. As everyone knows, many things will be considered in the context of the forthcoming Budget. I will see that the Treasurer's attention is drawn to this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I draw his attention to claims made by the Australian Science and Technology Council in a report it presented to the Prime Minister on the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region. I ask the Minister whether he will comment on this report and, in particular, on the claim by the Council that:

QUESTION.PARA: Research necessary to set safety standards and develop environmental protection regarding uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers Region is progressing far too slowly.

In view of the Government's commitment to the protection of the environment in the Alligator Rivers Region, I ask, firstly, what action will be taken by the Government to rectify the inadequacies which are causing delays in the research program? Secondly, has consideration been given by the Government to the Science and Technology Council's recommendation that the Government give impetus to its commitment to the environmental research program in the Alligator Rivers Region by building a permanent laboratory at Jabiru and by increasing the staff ceiling of the office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware of the report by the Australian Science and Technology Council, which was tabled here on 20 May. I can also advise Senator Missen of the Commonwealth's commitment to adequate environmental monitoring in the Alligator Rivers Region to remain as much in force as it always has as an integral part of our presence in the region, particularly while mining is carried on there. I am aware of the complexities of the report. I do not know how many honourable senators have read it since last Thursday, but on some of the matters the report advances quite complex arguments. For example, in his question Senator Missen refers to the location of a laboratory. I remind him , from his own reading of the report, that the decision reached by the Council was an on-balance decision between three different possible sites-a laboratory at Jabiru, Darwin or Sydney. The matters which have been raised will have to be the subject of decision by the Government, as they do involve policy questions. More than that, as to some of the detail, the Northern Territory Government will have to be involved. I advise the honourable senator that the Government is aware of the report and that it does take it seriously. It is aware of the issues raised and it reaffirms its commitment to the kind of environmental monitoring which I know is important to Senator Missen.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs . What obstacles remain to the ratification by the Australian Government of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women? When does the Government intend to ratify that Convention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to have that question referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
—You are the Acting Minister at the moment, are you not?

—That is right, and I have not in my mind at the moment the actions that need to be taken to ratify that Convention. The question will receive the early attention of the Department and I will see that Senator Ryan and the Senate are advised accordingly.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence: Have there been any requests from the Department of Defence to send observers to the Falkland Islands? If there have been no approaches, will the Government, as a matter of urgency, dispatch several senior officers from the armed Services, as observers, in a strictly non-combatant role? The opportunity to see this war first hand, particularly the maritime missile warfare which is the first of its kind, is extremely important and relevant to Australia's defence.

—I agree with Senator MacGibbon. In fact, I think I said a week or so ago in the Senate that obviously from what is taking place in the Falkland Islands area there are enormous lessons to be learned so far as defence is concerned. But I have no information regarding the substance of the question asked by Senator MacGibbon and I will have to refer it to the Minister for Defence.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. He will recall informing me on 31 March 1981 that the Australian National Railways had engaged a firm of corporate image consultants at a cost in excess of $408,000. Embodied in his answer was an estimated amount of $250, 000 for certain work to be carried out. The Minister will also recall that, during the debate on the appropriations for the Department of the Capital Territory and for the Department of Transport, Senator Peter Rae, last Wednesday, made an unwarranted attack upon my credibility, again referring to this matter. In view of the fact that the debate to which I have just referred was broadcast and attracted the attention of certain people listening to it who have since contacted me about certain matters, can the Minister tell the Senate whether there has been any escalation in the fee payable by Australian National Railways to the consultants over and above the figure he provided me with on 31 March 1981? If so, what is the total figure now involved?
—Off-hand I am unable to remember the exact amount that I mentioned in my answer on 31 March. I think it was of the order of $400,000.

—I thank the honourable senator. I will need to check that information. I recall that in the debate in this chamber last Wednesday night there was a reference, again by Senator McLaren, to that matter and that we became aware of the fact that that $408,000 covered not only the design of any logo or the change of name of the Australian National Railways Commission but also, of course, the whole detailed preparation of material such as the logo, stationery and the provision of material for rolling stock identification, and so on.
—You did not tell me that in your answer, did you? That is not in Hansard.
—Without going into that question, I think it was made perfectly clear last Wednesday night by Senator Peter Rae that in fact Senator McLaren's question was answered in my answer on 31 March 1981.
—That is what I am interested in-Senator Peter Rae's involvement in the whole matter.

—The honourable senator did not seek further information but he has now received further information. If he has any further information as to the amounts of expenditure I would be only too pleased to investigate further, provided he makes his claim specific.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to an article in today's West Australian newspaper in which it is reported that two Pilbara trade union officials were gaoled for non-payment of fines imposed as a result of convictions under section 202 1A of the Western Australian Road Traffic Code. I refer the Minister to the reported comments of the secretary of the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council, Mr Cook, who stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The union movement will not tolerate the gaoling of officials involved in legitimate union activities.

It is incredible. This was a picket line authorised by the TLC in applying a resolution that was unanimously carried by the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I ask the Minister: When the activities of members of the trade union movement perceived by the union movement to be legitimate union activities transgress the laws of a State or the Commonwealth, should those laws apply and the full force of the law prevail or do union members have immunity which is not available to other members of the public?

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a similar question asked of me last week, or a question which, although not in the same detail, raised the same issue of principle. I do not recall my exact answer but it would have been in the terms that I would use now, namely, that there is no immunity for any section of the community for breaches of the law. That applies in this situation and in others. Whether there should be penal sanctions with respect to the application of industrial laws is, of course, a matter of some controversy among some sections of the community. That is a quite separate issue, in my view. We are not dealing here with the question of the application of industrial laws relating to disputes about industrial conditions, and so on; we are dealing with breaches of the general law which applies to the whole community and which has nothing directly to do with industrial relations. In any event, it is certainly a desirable thing, in all aspects of the community's activities, that there should be the same rule for one as for any other member of the community. I do not believe that most Australians or, indeed, most members of the Opposition would regard the membership of a union or anything else as conferring immunity from the law.
