DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Ryan proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous effect of Fraser economic strategies on the local economy and employment opportunities in the Australian Capital Territory.
I call upon those honourable senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will know, seven years of Fraser government has meant falling living standards, rising unemployment, the undermining of an effective social welfare system and increased poverty throughout Australia. But nowhere have the consequences of Fraserism been so pervasive and so devastating as in the Australian Capital Territory. Constructed as the seat of government administration and falling solely under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth, the Australian Capital Territory has felt the full force of a government bent on withdrawing from its social responsibilities and diminishing public services. Under Fraser, Canberra citizens have felt very keenly the lack of any local or State government to cushion them from the consequences of Federal Government policies. Canberra provides the most clear-cut example of the failure of the Government's economic policies. Nowhere in Australia is that failure so evident as in the nation's capital. While the Government has cancelled public works, cut public expenditure , imposed staff ceilings and attempted to withdraw from public enterprise wherever possible, it has also failed dismally in getting private enterprise to step into the breach. So the Canberra economy has suffered a sharp decline and the people of Canberra-my constituents-have been the victims of all of this.

SPEECH.PARA: The employment situation in the Australian Capital Territory is unacceptable. In fact the rise in the number of unemployed locally is the most distressing result of nearly seven years of Fraser economic policies. Growth in employment opportunities in the Australian Capital Territory has failed to keep pace with even the relatively small population growth which has occurred during the last seven years. I have a graph taken from the 1980-81 annual report of the Department of the Capital Territory which clearly illustrates Australian Capital Territory employment and population trends since 1970. There was strong growth both in employment and in population figures until 1975. Thereafter, the population increased but there was a decrease in employment. Since 1975 population in the Australian Capital Territory has increased by approximately 39 ,000 and the total civilian work force has decreased by 1,2000. At this stage I seek leave to have this graph incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

—Mr Deputy President, I am happy to grant leave to incorporate the graph. There is a problem as to whether it can be printed in that form. The Government Printer might have some problems in printing it.

—I understand that there might be some problem in the printing of a graph in Hansard. If it can be arranged, subject to leave being granted, it will be arranged. I suggest that Senator Ryan seek leave at the same time to table the document.
—Mr Deputy President, I thank you and the Minister for your remarks . Mr Deputy President, following your advice, I seek leave also to table this document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Graph not incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Unemployment rates in Canberra have consistently exceeded the national average. The latest figures are no exception. While there was a small decline in the number of jobless registered nationally in March, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics there was another rise in the Australian Capital Territory. In Canberra the overall unemployment rate was 8.7 per cent in March as compared with 6.7 per cent nationally. For adolescents seeking full time time work the rate in Canberra was an appalling 28 .2 per cent compared with the national figure of 17.2 per cent. In the Australian Capital Territory 41 per cent of full time job seekers are aged between 15 years and 19 years. This compares with a figure of 30 per cent at the national level. Many of these young people have no choice but to leave Canberra to seek work elsewhere. It is worth noting that that is happening. If young jobless remained in the Australian Capital Territory the statistics would be even more appalling than those which I have just presented to the Senate. In the important 15-year-old to 24-year-old age group there has been a swing to net outward migration, which of course in itself further depresses the economy of the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the effect of Government policies on the private sector we find an equally depressing picture. Not only has the Government limited the growth of public employment through Public Service staff ceilings but also through cutbacks it has devastated the private sector, particularly the construction industry. Employment in private enterprise has suffered even more than public employment under the Fraser Government. In a Budget submission presented recently to the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), the Canberra Association for Regional Development said:

The mix of the economy is reverting to an increase in the public sector component-the private sector percentage has fallen from 40 per cent to 35 per cent in five years and is likely to fall further if corrective action is not taken.
Unemployment is being exported-and one breadwinner in five in the private sector is seeking employment elsewhere.

CARD points out that the reality of the Canberra economy is in direct conflict with the stated government policy of developing a strong private sector. Indeed, that is one of the ironies of the present situation, the situation which has developed ever since we have had a so-called private enterprise government running this Territory. The most serious losers in all this have been the people working in the private sector or the people who had their investment in the private sector.

There has also been a decline in government spending. The decline in government expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory has been the biggest single factor in causing unemployment and the decline of the private sector. The decline in government spending has been accompanied by a much larger decline in private capital expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory. I refer any senator who doubts what I am saying to the figures in the tables set out on pages 114 and 115 of the 1980 annual report of the Department of the Capital Territory. Those tables reveal that for 1974-75 expenditure by the Department of the Capital Territory amounted to $139m and $279m for the National Capital Development Commission. Total expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory amounted to $632m. In 1980-81 the budget for the Department of the Capital Territory had decreased to $96m and the NCDC budget had decreased to $112m in real terms, which is a decrease of more than 100 per cent. Total government expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory had decreased to $520m in real terms. The decline in government spending in real terms is huge but it must be pointed out, not nearly as large as the decline in private capital expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory which was more than halved in real terms since its peak in 1975-76. Private investment in the Australian Capital Territory is now estimated to be at its lowest level since 1969, reflecting the high failure rates for small businesses and the severe cutbacks in government contracts.

During 1981 the Government cancelled or deferred eight or possibly nine major projects which could have breathed life into the Canberra economy and provided some desperately needed employment. Construction of the Australian Federal Police headquarters, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation headquarters, the Archives building and the federal Courts was deferred. Construction of the Australian Institute of Criminology was cancelled. The future of the Museum of Australia is in doubt. The proposed hotel convention centre for Canberra has been rejected. Total private and government expenditure on housing and construction in the Australian Capital Territory has taken a nose -dive since the Fraser Government gained office. From a peak in 1975 of over $ 550m construction expenditure has declined steadily to only $185m this year. I have a graph from the Master Builders Association of the Australian Capital Territory illustrating this disastrous position. For the information of honourable senators, I seek leave to table the graph.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I would now like to proceed with a discussion on housing in the Australian Capital Territory. Honourable senators who have been familiar with the development of the Australian Capital Territory economy over many years will recognise that the housing industry has been or was until the incoming Fraser Government changed the situation, the backbone of the building and construction industry. The decline in the construction industry has been greatly exacerbated by the fact that this Government cancelled the construction program for government housing in the Australian Capital Territory in 1976 and has only this year been forced by the growing demands of those who cannot afford to buy or rent houses on the private market to recommence it. Again the decline in construction of government housing has been accompanied by a decline in construction of private housing, and this is an indication of the economic stagnation which this Government has brought to the national capital. In 1975, 5,068 new dwellings, 3,620 private houses and 1,448 government houses were completed in the Australian Capital Teritory. In 1980-81, only 1,971 houses were completed in the Australian Capital Territory, that is, 1,970 private houses and one government house. Despite the fact that the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, announced with a great flourish at the time of the last Federal Budget that 300 new government houses were to be built in 1981- 82, fewer than 10 government houses have been completed so far this year.

SPEECH.PARA: By the Government's own standards of economic responsibility, it has clearly been a dismal failure in the Australian Capital Territory. Any private enterprise that followed the course which this Government is pursuing would very quickly go out of business. What private employer would pursue a policy of arbitrary staff ceilings, leaving adequate staff in some areas but severe shortages in critical areas? The Fraser Government is guilty of very bad management and irresponsible decisions, such as dropping the construction of government housing and the selling of Canberra's major public asset-the Belconnen Mall.

The Minister for the Capital Territory attempts to cover up his Government's bad management by flamboyant announcements of major new projects. The main problem with these new projects is that they never eventuate. Let us look at a few examples. We are still waiting for any sign of the National Semiconductor Corporation of California silicon chip factory. Yet that was a proposal which the Minister announced as being the salvation of the employment situation and the economy of the Australian Capital Territory. This project does not exist. I express at this stage my deepest scepticism that we will ever see that manufacturing initiative in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister's most recent announcement was that a private enterprise film production project would be initiated in the Australian Capital Territory. Now it appears, from questions that have been raised in this chamber and in the other place, that the Government may have to close the tax loopholes which are facilitating the project by United American and Australasian Film Productions Pty Ltd. That is another project we are still waiting to see any sign of and which perhaps will not eventuate.

I put to honourable senators that the people of Canberra are sick and tired of listening to Mr Hodgman's promises of what will happen. The people of the Australian Capital Territory very clearly are aware of what has happened. That is their concern. That concern amounts to a judgment that the Fraser Government has been a dismal failure in this Territory. Even the local Liberal Party is doing its best to dissociate itself from the Federal Liberal Government and the Minister for the Capital Territory in the current House of Assembly election campaign. It is easy to see why. While Mr Hodgman is fond of slating Canberra bashers, his Government-the Fraser Liberal Government-is the biggest Canberra basher of all time. In this respect the Fraser Government is markedly different from its Liberal predecessors. Previous Liberal-National Country Party governments took some pride in developing the national capital, but this present small-minded Government has sought to downgrade Canberra and to disadvantage its people.

In the social welfare area the situation is particularly grim. I present more figures for the benefit of the Senate. In June 1975, 6,888 people, or 3.6 per cent of the population of the Australian Capital Territory, depended for their income on pensions and benefits. The figure for March of this year was 18,992- that is, 8.4 per cent of the population of the Australian Capital Territory. There has been an increase from 3.6 per cent to 8.4 per cent in the percentage of the local population being forced into dependency on government benefits. I defy any government which has presided over such an increase in poverty, misery and joblessness to argue that it has been anything other than a disaster. Relief agencies in the Australian Capital Territory, such as the Smith Family, the Salvation Army and the St Vincent de Paul Society-not to mention my own electorate office-are seriously overburdened by people who are in need of money, food, clothes and furniture.

One of the very unfair policies which the Government has implemented in this Territory is to force people on to charity. These days when constituents of mine who are in financial trouble or who have housing problems go along to one of the local departmental agencies for assistance they are directed, as a matter of government policy, to go and seek assistance from charities. We all acknowledge the excellent work done by charitable organisations in this community-no one is more aware of their excellent record than I am-but I consider it to be quite wrong that in the matter of basic living standards constituents are being directed to charities. There has been an absolute abrogation of responsibility to the poor and needy in this community, although their situation has been created as a direct result of the Fraser Government's economic policies.

The Capital Territory Health Commission has insufficient funds to continue to support crisis services such as the Canberra women's refuge, the Caroline Chisholm refuge and Lifeline. These bodies are now sent off to make submissions for grants from the recycled gambling money in the Australian Capital Territory Community Development Fund. It is another very good example of the attitude of the Government to the provision of social services in the Territory that the only funding available for these organisations is that derived from gambling revenue. Inadequate funding for the Office of Child Care has meant that the Black Mountain creche cannot obtain a government subsidy. It and other centres in the Australian Capital Territory have been forced to charge higher fees for child care and thus put their services outside the range of the parents and children who most need them. The creche at the Bruce College of Technical and Further Education must close because of the lack of government funding. That too will have ramifications. When a creche at a training institution such as Bruce College has to close many parents-in most cases mothers seeking to acquire labour market skills-have to cease studying and developing those skills and, as a consequence, are forced to remain unemployed, or beneficiaries of government benefits. So the whole disadvantage is accumulated as a result of inappropriate government policies. The increased burden on relief agencies, the increased demand for government funding and government housing, and the increasing number of people on pensions and benefits are all reflections of the economic strain placed on the people of the Australian Capital Territory by the policies of the Fraser Government.

There was a time when Canberra was regarded by all Australians and also internationally, as the great success story of growth centres. It is a planned growth centre and for many years, under a succession of governments of different hues, it was extremely successful. It was a thriving, growing place where people could look forward to economic security for themselves, to jobs and to economic security for their children. That has all changed in a way which not only has disadvantaged local residents but also, I believe, has been to the detriment of Australians generally, all of whom have a stake in this place and are being undersold by present government strategies.

On 5 June an election will be held in the Territory for the local House of Assembly, a body which at this stage has only an advisory role to the Government , but whose voice is the only voice which the Territory's citizens are allowed by the present Government to have in the running of their own affairs. This situation is extremely unsatisfactory from the point of view of anybody who believes in democratic principles. It has proven to be extremely unsatisfactory in that the policies which the Fraser Government has implemented, with or without-I would say mainly without-the advice of the local Assembly, or against its advice, have been disastrous. Surely, if people are allowed to elect spokespeople on local issues, we will end up with better policies than those to which we have been subjected for seven years. I believe that the people of the Australian Capital Territory will endorse, by the way they vote on 5 June, everything that I have said in the matter of public importance which I have brought before the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not at all surprising to find this issue raised by the honourable senator, as she has mentioned, in the context of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly election to be held on 5 June. I suppose it is reasonable that she should do so at this time in order to seek to influence votes for her own party by making capital out of this matter, but not along the most unreasonable lines that she has followed today.
—Just query one of those statistics; just query one of them.

—We will query some of those things a little later, Senator Ryan , and put them straight for the benefit of the people of the Australian Capital Territory so that they will properly understand the situation. That is an opportunity to which I look forward. In fact, in these next few minutes I hope we will be able to get the argument on to a proper basis for deciding, indeed, how the economic strategies of the Fraser Government have worked in practice, not only as they affect Australia but also in terms of their effects on the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the first thing that we ought to do is to attempt to test the arguments put forward by Senator Ryan in her speech today to to see what, in fact, policies of the Australian Labor Party type really mean in terms of success in State administrations. I suppose the obvious thing to do firstly is to turn to the most recent political event on the calendar which was the election last Saturday week of a new Liberal Government in Tasmania and the complete throwing out, holus-bolus, of a Labor government which was so discredited, so disorganised, so split, so faction ridden and so destroyed by its own activities that it deserves no further consideration. The kinds of strategies and the kinds of bleats that came from the former Tasmanian Government are the kinds of things that we heard from Senator Ryan today. She talked about the public sector involvement and the greater degree with which moneys can be spent on particular activities. This is the kind of thing which Senator Ryan sees as the only panacea for the problems of any economy and particularly for the government of the Australian Capital Territory.

Perhaps we ought to look at one or two other States. One State government that comes most quickly to mind which has a direct effect upon the residents of the Australian Capital Territory, is, of course, the New South Wales Wran Labor Government. If there is any example of the failure of Labor policies at State government level, it would have to be evidenced by that Government. There has been a lack of planning. Attention to political concerns rather than to the real interests of the people has been so paramount in the minds of the leadership of the Labor Party in that State and that attitude has resulted in the kinds of problems that will rub off on the Australian Capital Territory in the coming winter. We all know of the great power crisis in New South Wales-the problems of getting the power stations going in that State-and the difficulties that six years of Wran Labor Government in New South Wales have visited upon New South Wales.

We have seen this situation not only in the power area but also with regard to shipping as a result of the State Government's activity. Constant references have been made to 'Wran's navy', that pile of some 120 ships that sit off Wollongong, Sydney and Newcastle, unable to berth because of the problems brought about by a lack of loading facilities and because of industrial problems on the wharves of New South Wales. These are examples of the kinds of solutions which Senator Ryan would have us believe and accept as being the panaceas for the problems which she sees.

I have other examples. One is, of course, in my State of South Australia. Ten years of disastrous Dunstan Labor government in that State produced economic decline and stagnation in South Australia over that time. It is fortunate that, by the election of the Tonkin Liberal Government in 1979, this is now being turned around. We have seen an improvement in the economy of that State. We have seen the development of new job opportunities. Some 20,000 new jobs have been created in South Australia since that Government came to power. Why and how has this happened? It has happened through the power applications of the kind of commonsense, good housekeeping-approach which is antipathetic to the kinds of ideas which Senator Ryan put forward. We have seen the advent, in recent times, of the new Labor Government in Victoria. Already it has had to renege on promises which it made prior to the election of 3 April. Consequently this demonstrates that it already realises that its promises cannot be met.

What kinds of policies and what kinds of strategies, economic or otherwise, would Senator Ryan like to see us adopt here in the Territory. In recent times there has been some play by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, about what ought to be done to stimulate activity in the Australian Capital Territory. What kinds of things have emanated from him? He is the exponent, the front-runner, of all policies in relation to Australia and his economic expertise, at least amongst Labor Party people, seems to be well and truly accepted. The point is that people in the Australian Capital Territory have not had the opportunity of properly judging those policies simply because they have not been spelt out in any way. Neither Senator Ryan nor Mr Hayden, as Leader of the Opposition, has clearly said to us what they intend with regard to the Australian Capital Territory. Sure, there has been some bleating and some reports in newspapers about how we can spend our way out of the problems in the Territory. That sounds to me exactly like an extension of policies which have been proposed in respect of the whole of the Australian economy over the last six years. Those kinds of policies have been brought into absolute disrepute over that period by the very success of the Fraser Government's policies throughout Australia since 1975. We have seen a reduction of inflation and the creation of more jobs in the Australian economy. Some 200,000 jobs were created in 1980. These policies are bringing success.

What kinds of things would Senator Ryan put forward? She could spend her time more constructively in trying to explain to us how she would implement such policies so that the people of the Australian Capital Territory can properly judge what the ALP is proposing. I suppose the first things we should look at are the make work schemes which seem to be a common thread amongst all solutions found by the ALP. I am not sure whether that is a policy that Mr Hayden would put forward as a solution to the problems of the Australian Capital Territory but I remember well that in 1975, as Treasurer of this country, he wound up the Regional Employment Development Scheme. I take it that that sort of scheme is what he would like to see implemented in the Territory. Yet in 1975 that was the kind of policy to which he was opposed and which he realised was unproductive, too expensive and likely to increase taxation on the whole of the population, and which consequently would not lead to the kinds of benefits that he wanted. He recognised that in his more rational moments as an economic spokesman for the ALP and he implemented that policy when he had the power to do so when Treasurer of Australia in 1975. Is he now saying to us that that policy is to be reversed? Is he now going to argue that we should be spending more on make work schemes like the discredited RED scheme of 1975? Not even Clyde Cameron, a former Minister for Labour, supported that kind of policy in the end. He saw the damage that it was doing by creating more taxation on the people, destroying incentives and so destroying employment. These kinds of schemes have been discredited and yet they are coming forward again from the Labor Party. That is the situation as best as we can judge it. We need a clear statement of the Labor Party's policy. Certainly Senator Ryan has given no such clear statement today of what the ALP would do if it were in charge of the Treasury benches here in the Australian Parliament and could direct funds to the Australian Capital Territory.

There is one other point that ought to be mentioned. We heard from Senator Ryan , in the latter part of her speech, a reference to self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. All of us know that this Government allowed a referendum in 1978 of the citizens of the Territory and they overwhelmingly voted against self-government. Clearly the people of the Australian Capital Territory do not want self-government. Yet, Senator Ryan claims to have behind her supporters who do want self-government. Perhaps there are a few. Maybe there are some who do seek this kind of answer to their problems. But is there an answer to be found in self-government? I do not know that we can answer that question today. It is not the central point of this debate. But one point must be made in that regard and that is that this Government has empowered the Commonwealth Grants Commission to investigate the funding of the Australian Capital Territory in such a way as could possibly lead towards some kind of self -government. This indicates the sinews of what is required if any kind of self- government is ever to be achieved. This Government is interested in researching all possibilities, not closing off the options as Senator Ryan would have us believe in regard to the various issues that she has raised.

Coming down to some of the particular difficulties that have occurred in this economy and the Australian Capital Territory in recent times, we can easily find the answer to Senator Ryan's dilemma. On the one hand, she is seeking to make political capital out of the kinds of problems that have emerged with unemployment, but, on the other hand, she is not prepared to shape up to a proper analysis of the facts. The truth is that Canberra, during a period of very rapid growth over the last 20 years, particularly in the period preceding 1975, saw a movement among Commonwealth Government departments of people coming from other centres, such as Sydney and Melbourne, to Canberra. In other words, there were holus-bolus movements of groups into the Canberra area.

Naturally, this stimulated a very significant rate of growth in the Australian Capital Territory's economy. Since that time and as that process has slowed down , there has been only natural growth occurring in the Public Service in the Australian Capital Territory. Naturally enough, this has changed the whole atmosphere in this area. One could not have reasonably expected that there would have been a continuation of that process of continual transfer of departments from other centres to the Australian Capital Territory. Anyone with half a wit would understand that there are only so many departments that can be transferred to the Australian Capital Territory. That is the point that the Labor Party, Mr Hayden and Senator Ryan refuse to recognise.

The fact is that there must be a limit to the growth that can occur from that kind of stimulus. As a result of particular government activity since 1975, there has been a gradual growth in this area, not anywhere near as great as that in the period immediately preceeding it. But that is no reason for adopting new policies in relation to the Australian Capital Territory. If we had reached a certain point when the policies of transferring departments to the Australian Capital Territory had run into a brick wall, clearly there would be a need to adopt other policies. This Government is doing that. Through the present Minister, Mr Hodgman, we have seen a development towards the encouragement of more private enterprise development in Canberra. We have already seen his initiative in seeking to obtain the services of a film studio in Canberra. Obviously, the spin-off from that kind of activity is far greater than the amount of the original investment and it will stimulate enormous employment opportunities above and beyond those people directly involved in such a facility .

We have also seen the recent negotiations with National Semiconductor ( Australia) Pty Ltd in relation to the development of a factory in the Australian Capital Territory. The reason that that particular effort has not borne fruit at present is obvious. It is that there has been an international downturn in the economy. Clearly, that has changed the basis on which the economics of such a situation could be worked out and determined to be viable. Notwithstanding that, the fact is that Senator Ryan refuses to realise or to admit that the Federal Government was prepared, upon the receipt of the original proposals from the Nat -Semi organisation, to fund that process to the extent of $19m. An undertaking was given to that effect. Does that indicate that this Government has no interest in the development of alternative facilities in the Australian Capital Territory? Clearly, it does not. Clearly, the Government was prepared to put its money where its mouth is in relation to these kinds of processes. These things are the core of what this Government's strategy is about. Senator Ryan by no means has been able to prove to us that those policies have not been successful in the Australian Capital Territory.

Senator Ryan made a great deal of the problems of unemployment in the Australian Capital Territory, but the fact is that in April of 1982-these figures are provisional-those people seeking full time work represented around 5 per cent of the total work force in the Australian Capital Territory. That compares with the figure of 6.3 per cent for Australia as a whole. In terms of full time work seeking individuals, the Australian Capital Territory has an advantage over the rest of Australia. How does that stack up alongside the kind of argument Senator Ryan continues to put forward? Again we return to the sorts of solutions she talked of. She spoke of work creation schemes. What kind of work creation schemes?

TALK.START.PARA: —I never mentioned work creation schemes.

—Apparently the honourable senator's leader has because the statement has found its way into the media in some way or another. We know too that there have been attempts by this Government to develop alternative private sector activities as well. Of course we know of the growth of tourism in this area in recent times. I understand that the most recent statistics show that there has been substantial growth in tourism in the Australian Capital Territory . That relates directly to the Government's Australian Capital Territory tourism budget last year of some half a million dollars. Clearly this promotion expenditure is aimed at stimulating job opportunities in the Australian Capital Territory. Yet we still do not see any specifics coming forward from the Labor Party on what it would like to see happen. The lack of detail which emanates from the Opposition shows that its arguments are designed purely as political stunts and clearly they have no backing in terms of how they might solve the problems of the residents of the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: One piece of evidence Senator Ryan threw into the debate which deserves some answer is a comparison of the number of people on welfare benefits. I think she said that some 3.6 per cent of the total work force in 1975 was on various welfare benefits. That compares with the 1981 figure of 8.4 per cent. Those are Senator Ryan's figures; I am unable to check them. She seeks to make the point that somehow there is a greater and rising need by people who are on welfare, and that they may need specific help other than that available through the social security system. She fails to make the point that this could well be another example of that phenomenon which exists throughout the whole of the Australian community; that is, the gradual aging of our population, causing more people to move into the welfare area.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not here.

—I think it is fair to make the point that it could well be an example of that and we need more information about that comment. The overriding point I seek to make is that this Government's policies are aimed at stimulating alternative policies in the Australian Capital Territory. These things have been enunciated clearly by the Minister. He is actively promoting and seeking to promote Canberra wherever he can so as to develop alternative private sector development in the Australian Capital Territory. We know from listening to the radio every morning how active he is in this regard and how, through his various media activities, he is seeking to promote Canberra at every opportunity. The Opposition has not made out any case at all along the lines set down in the wording of the matter of public importance and the Government totally rejects its arguments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess to being a little surprised at Senator Messner's objection to Australian Capital Territory matters being discussed at this time when an election is due to be held in the Australian Capital Territory on Saturday week. I would have thought that this was the right time to discuss Canberra's affairs; certainly not the wrong time. Instead Senator Messner discussed extensively-certainly in the first part of his speech-the affairs of New South Wales and South Australia where, to my certain knowledge, an election is not to be held on Saturday week. That aside, the Australian Democrats are also concerned about the effects of the Fraser Government's economic policies in the Australian Capital Territory. In Canberra we see something of a microcosm of the failure of the Government's economic policies throughout Australia. I think this is really the crux of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We see, both in the larger field and in the smaller field of the Australian Capital Territory, a society in which every day more and more families are entering the ranks of the poor. People who once regarded themselves as being reasonably well off are now struggling with much higher taxation in real terms, much higher interest rate charges on their home loans and rising costs over virtually the whole spectrum of family costs. Whatever one cites as statistics and cost of living tabulations, one has only to speak to any housewife in Canberra or elsewhere to get the same story, that it is becoming increasingly difficult for more and more people to make ends meet. We have a society in which , apparently, unemployment remains a major and intractable problem. The economy generally is in the doldrums, lacking the drive and initiative that a great and lucky country such as Australia should have. Because of artificial restrictions on the economy we have that problem and we will continue to have the problem as long as those artificial restrictions exist and these crude monetarist views of the economy are held. That is being demonstrated all over the world.

Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory are especially vulnerable to such things. As such, Canberra is a classic case of the need for remedial treatment. This is needed in Canberra urgently. It needs treatment to cushion the community against the fluctuating economic fortunes of society. The obvious answer would seem to be-others have said this along with the Australian Democrats-to broaden the economic base and to do so progressively from now on. The Government has certainly expressed a national policy of extending the private enterprise base. However, the effect of what has happened is that in the Australian Capital Territory the private sector contribution to the local economy has fallen by at least 5 per cent in the last five years and is likely to continue its downward spiral unless corrective action is taken immediately. In fact, it ought to have been taken much earlier.

We feel that the Government's lack of real interest in the welfare of the Australian Capital Territory is evidenced by this absence of a coherent, long term and disciplined program for the economic development of the Territory. As I shall describe later, a rational and achievable program of that kind has been put forward only today by the Australian Democrats leader in the House of Assembly, Mr Gordon Walsh, on his behalf and on behalf of his colleague in the House of Assembly, Mr Ivor Vivian. Indeed, he spoke on behalf of all the Australian Democrats in Canberra. I understand that the Australian Democrats in Canberra regard economic recovery in the Australian Capital Territory as probably the most important area of Democrats policy for next month's election. That should be so because it is the most serious problem facing Canberra.

I have been to shops and various arcades in Canberra talking to people. It is a fact that Canberra is seen now-certainly by retailers-as one of the most difficult places in Australia in which to run a business. White goods, clothing and commodities of that sort are cheaper in Canberra than they are anywhere else . They have to be sold cheaply to be moved. I think that is a serious situation. We find that, faced with this situation, the Government prefers to proceed with random, ad hoc, hit or miss policies for the Australian Capital Territory, apparently in the interest of short term political gain; that is, if it even bothers to consider the effects of its economic policies on the Territory at all . There is increasing evidence that the Government is not considering that.

The Government's Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has praised a recent submission from the Canberra Association for Regional Development, CARD, which calls for a five-year rolling public works program for the Australian Capital Territory. Mr Hodgman has called the CARD submission excellent, which is a very strong word. It means that it cannot be better. Mr Hodgman stated that the submission presents a very good argument. However, the Government's cynicism towards the Australian Capital Territory seems, to the Australian Democrats, to be evident in that its Minister, Mr Hodgman, regards the chances for success of this excellent proposal-to use his own word-as doubtful. That is not nearly good enough as an answer to the problems of the people of Canberra. I think it even gives an element of levity to a serious situation.

In November 1978 the Government predicted an annual public works expenditure for the Australian Capital Territory of $165m in the year 1978 to be increased gradually to a figure of $375m by 1985-86. In fact, the reverse of the Government's projections has occurred. Since 1978 public works spending fell from $165m to $95m by 1982. This figure represents a shortfall of $131m in the Government's projections, which called for $226m in public expenditure for this year. That is obviously one of the reasons for the economic effects which the people of Canberra notice so greatly. In this uncertain climate it is not difficult to understand why the private sector is not able to pull itself up by its own bootstraps through self-help efforts, or why other businesses steer clear of investing in the Australian Capital Territory. The Government tends to watch its ideological magic formula, that somehow if everything is left to private enterprise, even the most unpromising circumstances, it will get things together. The Australian Democrats are a private enterprise party too; we are particularly concerned with small business. We are appalled at the terrible beating about the head which the Government is giving to small business in this country and the advantage it is giving to large business, particularly multinational business. We are not particularly multinational baiting or bashing ; there is very much a part for the multinational companies to play in the development of this country in a controlled, planned way. The fault is not in the multinationals but in the Government because of the emphasis that it is giving to the situation with regard to small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —All you have suggested so far is new buildings.

—In today's economic climate it is naive to expect small or large business to come to Canberra in the teeth of the wild fluctuations of Canberra's fortunes that are associated with changes in government policy. I heard early one morning last week a radio program in which a building expert spoke to young people in Canberra about whether they should go ahead and build a house. He came out quite directly and said: 'Do not ever consider building a house in Canberra. Do not any of you try to build a house in Canberra because it is a fact that you will buy a house-and there are plenty of houses on the market in Canberra- cheaper than you could build one'. That in itself is very serious. It is a significant and important indicator of what is wrong in Canberra. Additionally, it is unlikely to encourage many builders to come to Canberra or to want to stay here. It is hypocritical for the Government to urge private enterprise to assume greater economic responsibility when the Government's own piecemeal policies make the success of private enterprise in Canberra all but impossible. That is the truth of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: As Government expenditure provides the major impetus for economic growth in the Territory, cuts in the expenditure of the magnitude just outlined have resulted in serious economic dislocation. I made the point when I first rose to speak that Canberra is particularly vulnerable to economic dislocation for the reason that it does not have the versatility and diversity of income and business that it ought to have. The effects of this economic dislocation have rebounded very substantially on the young. This is a serious matter too. While the national level of unemployment declined slightly in March, in the Australian Capital Territory that figure increased. One-third of the unemployed in the Territory are between the ages of 15 and 19. The unemployment rate for people of that age nationally is 17.2 per cent. As I have said before many times in this place, that is a shocking indictment of the Government's economic policies both in human and social terms as well as economic ones.

In the Australian Capital Territory that already outlandish figure for unemployed youth of 17.2 per cent nationally becomes 28.2 per cent-well over one -quarter of the young people in Canberra are seeking jobs and cannot get them. The overall unemployment rate for young people and adults combined is 2 per cent higher than the national average and stands at 8.6 per cent. Because of this high level of youth unemployment, it is not surprising to learn that there is a significant and growing trend of out-migration by that age group of 15 to 24. That is a serious matter too. It means essentially that this community can offer no future to its young people. A more savage fate could hardly be visited upon it by even an ill-intentioned government.

As well, there are an estimated 9,000 to 10,000 underemployed or unemployed people in the Australian Capital Territory. What is worse, the Canberra Association for Regional Development has estimated that if private business fails to develop an industrial and commercial base by 1988-that is only six years off-the children now in primary schools in the Australian Capital Territory will feel the full effect of the stagnation and those now in secondary schools will have to go elsewhere to find work. This would make inevitable a split-up of their families and an impossibility for them to be in their family circle during those first vital years when they work which, as most people would accept, is a desirable situation. Already at present one in five breadwinners not employed in the government sector will have to go elsewhere to find employment. I cannot emphasise strongly enough that these are not merely statistics or percentages. They are a description of Australian people in the Australian Capital Territory who are denied their right to earn a simple and decent living. That is all they ask for and they have been denied it. As I have said here before, and will say again, that represents a fundamental failure of government and its responsibilities.

Perhaps some other specific examples can highlight the situation. The National Capital Development Commission's works program has been steadily reduced by 40 per cent in 1980 and by another 30 per cent in 1981. Even if we include money allocated to the new and permanent Parliament House and the Defence Academy, the program decline in recent years has been in the range of 15 per cent in money terms and, if inflation is taken into account, 25 per cent in real terms. Residents of the Australian Capital Territory are also hard hit by household rates, which have recorded percentage rises in double figures in recent years. The difficulties I have mentioned indicate clearly that urgent action by the Federal Government is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are your solutions?

—By 1988 all existing major building projects, including the new and permanent Parliament House and the Defence Academy, will have been completed . If a five-year rolling public works program is to be initiated, the time for action is now. I come to the point raised by Senator Thomas. If he would like to get a copy of the policy statement of the Australian Democrats in the Australian Capital Territory, which was issued this morning, he can read our proposals in detail. I will outline a few of them: That sensible and realistic incentives to attract business to Canberra, no worse than those offered to or operating in a State, be developed and that policies be designed to promote and enlarge existing Canberra businesses with the opportunity of gaining increasing employment opportunities. As I have said before, that is vital for youth. If they want to leave there will be more--
—More tariffs.
—Did the honourable senator say 'more tax'? One of the fundamental Liberal Party fallacies is that tax is generated by generating employment.
—I said 'more tariffs'.

—I am sorry. I have not time to discuss that matter now. Certainly I would not make the tax point, because a tightening up of the economy is causing the troubles that we have. What is much more important, the second point made by the Democrats in the Australian Capital Territory is that a housing trust be established and an expanded government house building program be started in Canberra. That would have to be associated with greater prosperity. The housing problem in Canberra is due to the strangling of the economy here. We should also seek greater community involvement in planning and environmental matters, indeed in all matters in the Territory. The Australian Democrats believe that these things should be done in reasonable consultation with the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats want to make Canberra a city in the fullest and truest sense-a vital viable community that is economically and socially balanced. Our representatives in the House of Assembly will persist with that policy for as long as it is necessary to get results. We want action from the Government to get things moving in the Australian Capital Territory again. We do not expect miracles in the current economic scene, but we want some rational policies. Some specific proposals such as those incorporated in the overall plan proposed by CARD which was commended and recommended to the Government by the Minister for the Capital Territory ought to be brought in and implemented as soon as possible .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Ryan, near the end of her speech, mentioned 5 June as the date of the election because it gave some point as to why we were discussing the Australian Capital Territory today. I think it is quite wrong of Senator Mason to suggest that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) was objecting to discussing the Australian Capital Territory. The examples he gave of Australian Labor Party mismanagement in other places were merely designed to remind the people of the Australian Capital Territory of the sort of future they could expect in this Territory should ever a Labor Government again be elected to office.

SPEECH.PARA: To look at the situation accurately, we need to go back a little. There was a particularly high growth rate between 1972 and 1975, so much so that even the Labor Government at the time saw the need for a slow-down and saw the absurdity of the growth rate which it had created. Staff ceilings were introduced in July 1975 by the then Labor Government. The Public Service Board report for 1975 commented upon the decrease of 4.2 per cent during the 1975-76 year when it stated:
In July 1975 the Government approved a 1.5 per cent ceiling on operative staff growth for 1975-76.

Certainly other staff ceilings have been imposed since then, but it was started by the Labor Government, which saw the need for it. There were other cutbacks at the same time, in the era of the Labor Government. These were referred to in 1975-76 National Capital Development Commission annual report.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was seven years ago, Senator.
—There is some point in its being seven years ago, and I will refer to it in this quote from NCDC report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: In many instances the effects of financial restraints now being imposed to meet short-term economic problems will not be felt for a number of years hence. This situation has occurred during 1975-76 because of the curtailment of much of the Commission's forward planning work and through delays in commencing new works for which the future need is clear.

Page 14 of the same report refers to one of the projects which, of course, is just now being completed; it refers to the slow-down at the time in the construction of the Australian National Gallery. Many honourable senators will recall the anguish felt in this community in 1975 at the Labor Party's proposal to move public servants out of Canberra. I refer in passing to the National Mapping Council as one instrumentality which was to be moved. What would have happened to Canberra had the Government not changed in 1975? Perhaps we can get some idea of that from Senator Ryan's speech today, which was totally negative talk about the future of Canberra. That does nobody any good.

The Australian Capital Territory is not in as bad shape as the ALP would have us believe, but for electoral purposes the ALP is prepared to talk in this manner. It is time the ALP stopped electoral point scoring and started looking towards the welfare of Canberrans. That party is obsessed with doom and this sort of knocking is not likely to encourage the private sector to bring its money to Canberra and to develop it. The only thing the ALP has to offer in its policy for the House of Assembly election is more expenditure of taxpayers' money on work creation schemes, which are band-aid measures. The Australian Capital Territory is looking for employment opportunities for young people, opportunities that are worth while and will create career prospects for them. It is important that Canberra develop a base other than a public service one. I think all public servants would agree that it is important that there be a thriving private sector so there is opportunity for their children to obtain other types of jobs. We have heard from the Labor Party no proposals for development. It knocked the National Semiconductor Corporation scheme and the Tivoli Gardens scheme. It knocks any development proposal that is put up.

The Labor Party has referred to self-government, and I also refer briefly to that. Self-government was promised by the Whitlam Government, but what happened? Absolutely nothing. This Government held a referendum in 1978 to ascertain the views of the community, and they were given to us in the result of that referendum. This Government is taking positive steps to ascertain the financial situation so that the people of the Australian Capital Territory can know the financial implications of taking over what is referred to as self-government that the Labor Party would thrust upon this community. The Commonwealth Grants Commission is inquiring into the financial situation here to ascertain the relationship of those aspects of government which now apply. That could have been done by the Whitlam Government, but it did not bother to do anything about it. No details are given to this community as to what self-government under a Labor Government would mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —It means you will have to look after yourselves for a change.

—There is no indication whatsoever as to whether there would be one chamber or two, whether there would be full time or part time members, whether there would be remuneration or allowances, whether there would be Ministers, a Speaker, a President or what the costs would be. There is no indication as to the financial arrangements that would exist between the Commonwealth and the local community, no indication of the functions which would be given to the local community and no indication of those functions which would be retained by the Commonwealth. If the Labor Party does not think it is important to the people of this Territory to know those things, I think it is very mistaken.

SPEECH.PARA: Undermining investment confidence is something the Labor Party is developing into a fine art, along with the Australian Democrats. This was evidenced in the attitude that at least one of its branches adopted to the Belconnen Mall. If anyone were to tell me that the Federal Government should be in the business of retailing, I would not be able to understand how that conclusion could be arrived at. Capital works programs are going ahead in the Australian Capital Territory at present. In the current year $650m worth of capital and recurrent programs are under way in the Australian Capital Territory. That, I think, is a very significant investment. Of that, $80.3m is set aside for the National Capital Development Commission for building and construction and $30m for the new Parliament House and the proposed Australian Defence Force Academy. There are a number of private projects: Blocks of offices are being built in Hobart Place; a commercial development is being undertaken opposite the Travelodge motel in Civic; and the old Jolimont building site is being developed. The Defence Force Academy, when completed, will bring about 1,200 people to Canberra . Also, a four-storey building in Mort Street has just been completed.

In the 1980-81 financial year $7.5m was spent on the new Parliament House and $ 23m has been set aside for this 1981-82 financial year. Only today, at lunch time, honourable senators will have heard on the news about a housing display held in conjunction with the Civic Co-operative Permanent Building Society Ltd and the Housing Industry Association of Australia. It is a 15-house display, the largest ever in the Australian Capital Territory, and there is strong competition amongst builders to participate in it. A block in Mort Street changed hands just a week or so ago for more than $2m. These are significant facts that need to be taken into account.

We, of course, have a fair idea of the Labor Party's attitude. The fact is that the Commonwealth Government's commitment to the Australian Capital Territory is clear. Senator Grimes interjects with parish pump just about every time I ask a question about the Australian Capital Territory, so the local electors can have a very fair idea of the attitude of the Labor Party to this community. Honourable senators may know that the shadow Minister for the Australian Capital Territory is also the shadow Minister for Defence. Defence, of course, is a most significant matter, yet the Australian Capital Territory portfolio is merely tacked on to it in the shadow ministry arrangements of the Labor Party. The Canberra Development Board has recognised the need for private sector development in the Australian Capital Territory and has identified higher technology and tourism as significant areas for development. It was this Government which invited the private sector to put up a submission on incentives to attract private enterprise to this community, and I think that should not be forgotten. In the last Budget the largest amount ever was allocated to the Australian Capital Territory Tourist Bureau to attract tourists. The effect of that campaign was very noticeable indeed, with an increased number of people in Canberra during the Easter period this year. The private sector is better organised in this Territory than it has ever been. It is investing in the community. More than ever there are things for tourists to do when they come to Canberra and more than ever there are things to encourage them to stay overnight in the Australian Capital Territory.

I refer now to sport. Honourable senators may think that is not significant in this context, but I suggest it is, in that it creates tourism and jobs. The Australia Day sports carnival has been held for three consecutive years, this last year totally without Federal Government assistance. People who are familiar with these sorts of things commented most favourably on the organisation of it. In other areas we have the National Sports Centre-mainly occupied by the tenant, the Australian Institute of Sport-which is also used for major sporting activities. Perhaps I could tell honourable senators of the Mazda Cannons, the local basketball team playing in a national competitions at home and away; the Canberra Arrows, who play in the national soccer league; and the Canberra Raiders rugby team, which plays in a competition in New South Wales which is effectively, I think, a national competition. Canberra is coming of age. Sheffield Shield cricket matches were played here last summer. Honourable senators would all know that the International Amateur Athletic Federation World Cup meeting will be held in Canberra in 1985; not just because those teams decided to come here but because the Federation had put to it a proposal of such calibre, presenting to it facilities for sport in Canberra that the teams have chosen to come here instead of Tokyo, which was the other applicant city. To suggest that nothing is happening in the Australian Capital Territory is absurd. Some honourable senators may have enjoyed the performance of the opera Aida which was presented by the Canberra Opera Society in the National Sports Centre. That was no small feat for a community of this size. Again, some honourable senators may think that that is not relevant but I suggest that it gives an indication of the attitude, enthusiasm and morale of this community.

A number of other businesses have opened in Canberra in recent times. I refer, for instance, to the $2m sawmill at the Hume industrial estate and the proposal by United American and Australasian Film Productions for a film studio which has already been referred to in this debate. The latter will bring to Canberra a great deal in the way of jobs and tourism and will be an added attraction to this city, apart from the skilled opportunities it will offer. I mention briefly the sale of the Belconnen Mall for those who are concerned about it. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has said quite clearly that space is to be made available, as is proposed at present, for community groups and that a subsidy will be paid as it is currently paid. White Industries Limited has put forward a proposal for an international hotel containing a major convention centre, banqueting hall and other features which will leave the Glebe Park area largely untouched. That expression of interest is presently being considered by the Department with a view to future development in that area.

To suggest that nothing is happening in Canberra and that it is stagnating in the way that speakers in this debate have suggested is designed, I think, to mislead this community and deter the private sector from coming to Canberra and investing here. As a result of the activities of the present Minister, Canberra is now getting back $3m a year from the gambling activities of Victoria and New South Wales which take place in Canberra. It is a significant achievement by the Minister to have brought that revenue back here. We all know how involved he was in getting the film studio proposal brought to Canberra. We have been well served by our present Minister. The community has been well served also by the Liberal members of the House of Assembly who have been in the Assembly since its last election. The Minister has criticised the Assembly. Senator Ryan has said it is unsatisfactory. Mr Ellicott said it was not working. I think we all know why it has not worked. When the Labor Party was elected on the last occasion it chose to embark on a series of acts of confrontation. It in no sense understood the role of the Assembly as an advisory group to advise the Minister. It has no understanding whatever of what might be consensus in putting matters together which would be of benefit to the Minister. I think the failure of the Assembly lies firmly at the feet of the Labor Party and no doubt the same thing will continue in the future if it adopts the same attitude to the Australian Capital Territory as it has in the past.
