PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement concerning some aspects of the alleged social security conspiracy case which arose out of the debate in the Senate on 14 October last year and questions which have been asked of me in relation to the matter, particularly by Senator Grimes, and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

On 14 October 1981, in the course of a debate on a matter of public importance raised by Senator Grimes, I said that I would try to get further information about proceedings that have been instituted in Greece against nine persons for alleged offences against the Australian Government in connection with what has come to be called the alleged social security conspiracy. I said also that I would consider making a statement to the Parliament about the matter. I confirmed my intention to make a statement in answer to a question without notice from Senator Grimes on 10 March.

2. Honourable senators will be aware that committal proceedings on charges of conspiracy are still in progress in Sydney against twenty defendants. Those proceedings resumed on 13 April 1982 when addresses on behalf of the defendants were commenced. It will be appreciated that we all need to be careful to ensure that nothing that is said in this House will prejudice in any way the fair conduct of the case in Sydney. Any reference to details of the allegations against any of the persons charged in Greece could be relevant to the charges of conspiracy before the court in Australia because those allegations concern similar conduct that is said to have taken place in Australia. Accordingly it would not be proper for me to discuss in any detail the evidence in relation to the persons charged in Greece.

3. I now have available to me a good deal of material relating to the proceedings in Greece, much of which has come from the Australian Federal Police . I also believe that my Department has records of all material relevant to the proceedings in Greece that are obtainable from official sources in Greece. Against this background, may I outline the history of exchanges between Australian officials and officials of the Greek Government.

4. In June and July 1978 and in January/February 1979 two officers of the then Commonwealth Police went to Athens and presented there requests for assistance in the investigation of a number of criminal matters in Australia. The first request for assistance was signed by the then Deputy Crown Solicitor, Sydney, in June 1978. On 24 January and 1 February 1979 I signed two other requests for assistance. The request for assistance stated that the Commonwealth Police desired to obtain information from nine named persons formerly residents of Australia who it was believed were involved in the alleged Social Security conspiracy and who were then residents of Greece.

5. All nine of these persons have since been charged in Greece in respect of alleged breaches of Greek law committed in Australia. Senator Grimes has said that the requests for assistance were in fact requests to the Greek Government to charge on behalf of the Australian Government people whom the Australian Government could not extradite (Hansard page 1173). I categorically deny that the requests for assistance were made for the purpose attributed to them by Senator Grimes.

6. Reports by the officers of the Commonwealth Police who visited Greece in 1978 and 1979 make it clear that evidence was given on oath in Greece of the alleged complicity of persons named in the requests for assistance in the conspiracy in Australia. These reports also make it clear that copies of certain documents from Australia were taken to Greece and were given to the Greek police authorities. It was necessary that documents be given to those authorities so that they could carry out the investigations that had been requested to be made. It should be noted in this regard that it is not permissible for Australian police themselves to carry out investigations in Greece. It is necessary when investigations are sought to be made in Greece that they be made by the Greek police. I have obtained from the Australian Federal Police copies of documents written in the Greek language which appear to be partial records of the information given on oath to an examining officer of the Greek judicial system by the senior Australian police officer who went to Greece and these documents have been translated. The first of the documents appears to be a statement made on oath in Athens on 24 July 1978. That statement is, I believe, identical with parts of 'the second document' to which Senator Grimes referred in his statement to the Senate on 14 October 1981 (Hansard page 1173). Another document that has been translated is entitled 'Statement of an Examined Witness through an Interpreter' and purports to record in part a statement again made by the same officer in Greece on 13 February 1979. This document appears to be a copy of what Senator Grimes referred to as 'a Court report of the Court of the First Instance of 13 February 1979' (Hansard page 1173).

7. I should say here that the documents that I was able to obtain through official channels relating to this case that are in Greek language appear to be incomplete. I therefore caused efforts to be made through the Australian Embassy in Athens to obtain a complete record of testimony given by the Australian police officer to Greek authorities. These efforts were not successful. I was informed that if testimony given by an Australian police officer in Greece was part of the investigation in that country it would be regarded as secret. Accordingly I took up an offer that Senator Grimes made in relation to the documents in his possession and obtained from him what appear to be complete records, in English, of the testimony given by the senior Australian police officer who went to Greece. Those records have been examined. There is nothing in that material to show that a request was made to the Greek authorities for proceedings to be taken against any person in Greece. Certainly nothing in the material that I have shows that any such request was made. It is true that the police officers who went to Greece were aware at all relevant times that persons resident in Greece could be charged under Greek law with offences in respect of things done in Australia. But they did not ask for proceedings to be taken. The testimony given in Greece was, I believe, given in connection with the examination of witnesses whom the Australian police had gone to Greece to interview. It seems clear that the evidence given in February 1979 was given because the Australian police officer was called before an examining magistrate and was required to give on oath an outline of the case to be presented in Australia.

8. The fourth document referred to by Senator Grimes on 14 October 1981 is a report of the Council of Magistrates of Athens released on 2 May 1980. A copy of a similar document is also in my possession. The document that I have records an order of the Council of Magistrates that the nine persons named should be tried in Greece for offences consisting of conduct in Australia. It also orders the arrest of some of those nine persons. I understand that, of those arrested, all are now on bail and that none is in custody. Senator Grimes claims that all the evidence against those persons was evidence supplied by Australian Police. The documents themselves do not establish this. But even if it were true that the evidence relied upon by the Council of Magistrates was evidence that Australian police offices were required to give in Greece as part of their investigation of alleged offences in Australia, it does not follow that the proceedings in Greece were initiated by those police officers and still less by the Australian Government. It should be said here that it was the clear understanding of the Australian police officers concerned that the Greek authorities would not institute any proceedings in Greece against those of the nine persons named in the Australian requests for assistance who gave evidence in Australia and were indemnified against prosecution in Australia.

9. I have reason to believe that the authorities in Greece may be under the impression that it was the wish of the Australian Government that the persons named in the Australian requests for assistance should be prosecuted in Greece. If that is the fact then there has been a misunderstanding of the purpose of the requests for assistance made by the Australian Government.

10. I turn now to the action that has been taken by the Australian Government in relation to the persons who have been charged in Greece. Special representations have been made on a number of occasions to the Greek Government about the fact that three of the persons who are being prosecuted in Greece have been indemnified or pardoned in Australia. The first of these representations was made on 8 September 1980.

11. On 30 October 1980 the court hearing the committal proceedings in Sydney was informed that the Crown had decided not to proceed with conspiracy charges against 111 defendants who had been charged with conspiracy, but in respect of whom committal proceedings had not been commenced. The Court was also informed that summonses for other substantive offences against the Crimes Act would be laid against those defendants in respect of whom evidence was available. In fact , summonses were issued against 73 of those defendants for the substantive offences against the Crimes Act. No further proceedings were instituted against the other 38 defendants who were discharged by the court on 14 November 1980. These matters were the subject of considerable publicity. I am confident that the Greek Embassy in Australia was aware of the developments.

12. Since October 1980 there have been at least six approaches by the Australian Government to the Greek Government or to the Greek officials about the proceedings in Greece. I have already informed the Senate of much of the action that I have taken. On 23 January 1981 I wrote to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and asked that detailed advice which I provided as to the state of the proceedings in Sydney be passed on to the Greek Government. Due to a misunderstanding by the Department of Foreign Affairs this was not done. However , I wrote in June 1981 to the Minister for Justice in Greece about the case of the three persons who had been indemnified or pardoned in Australia. I also mentioned, in general terms, the fact that late in 1980 it was decided that the Crown would not proceed in Australia against some of the persons originally arrested in 1978. In December 1981, the then Acting First Assistant Crown Solicitor had discussions with the Ambassador of Greece about the matter. On 25 February 1982 a senior officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Crown Solicitor had further discussions with the Ambassador of Greece in the course of which it was made clear that the Australian Government does not request proceedings against any of the persons charged in Greece.

13. The Australian Government has received a request for judicial assistance by way of supplying evidence from the investigating magistrate in Athens in relation to six of the persons who have been charged in Greece. We had been led to believe that such a request might be made because on 9 November 1981 officers of my Department learnt from unofficial sources that it was claimed that a request had already been sent early in 1981. A formal request was received in the Department of Foreign Affairs on 4 March 1982 and was forwarded to my Department on 19 March 1982. The Government has, now, informed the Greek Government through the Embassy of Greece that it cannot provide the assistance that has been requested. Two of the people to whom the request related have been indemnified against prosecution in Australia in respect of the matters for which they are under investigation in Athens. It is unlikely that the remaining four would now be facing any or any serious charges in Australia. The Government has informed the Greek Government that in all the circumstances it would be inconsistent with the attitude which the Government takes for it to provide the assistance that has been requested. We have welcomed the request for assistance because it has given us the opportunity to place formally before the judicial authorities in Greece the Australian Government's position in this matter. Hitherto we have had some difficulty in making our position known to the Greek judicial authorities through existing lines of communication.

14. The latest information available in relation to the proceedings in Athens is that the matter is in the hands of the Investigating Magistrate appointed by the Public Prosecutor of the Court of Appeals. When the investigating magistrate has completed his inquiries he will report to the Council of Magistrates of the Court of Appeals which will decide whether any or all of the defendants will stand trial in Greece. It is not known when the investigating magistrate will complete his inquiries.

15. In conclusion, I want to stress that the government has been at pains to ensure by any means at its disposal that its position is known to the Greek Government and to Greek authorities. We have done as much as I think it is possible to do to correct any misunderstandings that may have arisen about the position we take with respect to the proceedings in Greece. We will continue representations to the Greek authorities and will promote by whatever means are open to us an early and satisfactory conclusion to the proceedings in Greece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I wish to make a few remarks on this matter. The statement arises out of a matter of public importance raised by me on behalf of the Opposition and repeated questions about the involvement of the Australian Government, directly or through its agents, in the charges which are laid in Greece against people accused of offending against Australian law in Australia. What happened was that in April 1978, two years after the original arrests were made in Sydney which led to what is known as the social security case, we noticed in the Sydney Daily Telegraph in May 1980 a report that nine persons had been indicted in an Athens court under Greek law on charges known as fraud against the Australian Government. We found that report disconcerting because at that time no person had been found guilty of these offences in Australia. That situation exists now. We were unaware of the fact that certain people had been given immunity from being charged in Australia and we were concerned later on also about the answers we got from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Minister for Social Security at that time regarding this case.

The charges that were laid in Greece were similar to those which were laid in the case in Australia. They involved the same incidents and some of the same characters, on both the defence and prosecution sides. The matter attracted my attention firstly because the charges were laid in Greece under Greek law for offences committed in Australia. This was something which we found unusual and later on disturbing. Secondly, we noted that three of the people charged were people who had been given immunity or who had been indemnified from being charged in Australia. Thirdly, the matter has been of concern because the vast majority of those people who were originally charged and arrested in Sydney have had the charges against them withdrawn. Fourthly, we believe that the statements made by the inspector in charge of the case, then Detective Inspector Thomas, and given to the Greek authorities were misleading and were outside the knowledge of the Attorney-General or the Minister for Administrative Services ( Mr Newman). Finally, we believe those statements could have been construed by the Greek authorities only as statements of fact rather than allegations and that they could have been construed only as a request that charges be laid under Greek law. Bearing in mind all of those things, we do not believe that the statement put down today by the Attorney-General is a satisfactory one and we certainly do not think that it closes this case.

I will look at the statement page by page, although I realise I am not in a position to and should not hold up the Senate on this matter at the moment. Senator Durack, the Attorney-General, on page 2 of the statement first of all denies that the requests for assistance to the Greek authorities were made for the purposes of having these people charged in Greece. I suggest that that is true as far as the Attorney-General of this country is concerned. When he signed the request he may not have intended that it be used as a request for the purposes of having people charged under Greek law. I suggest that the evidence to which I referred in the matter of public importance, particularly the documents we got from Greece, shows that although the Attorney-General may not have thought that, Detective Inspector Thomas, as he was then, certainly thought that when he was the senior police officer in charge of what has been known as the conspiracy case or the social security case. He certainly believed that his job was to pursue people in this country and in Greece under Australian law and Greek law.

On page 4 of the statement the Attorney suggests that there is nothing in the material to show that a request was made to the Greek authorities for proceedings to be taken against any person in Greece. We know, for instance, that these documents are not a complete record of all meetings in Greece between Detective Inspector Thomas and the Greek authorities. But Detective Inspector Thomas was aware at the time that these people could be charged and his testimony to the Greek authorities, in documents which have been available to the Parliament and to the Attorney-General, does not only present the Crown case but also states as a fact that the people to whom he was referring were members of a conspiracy. I quote from the translation from the Greek record of the evidence given by Detective Inspector Thomas. He said:

These applications were based on false and bogus evidence supplied by a number of medical practitioners who had agreed to do so if the would-be applicants for an age or invalid pension agreed to pay . . .

The statements of the Detective Inspector were in this vein. They were not so couched as to imply that there were alleged offences. They were statements under oath containing assertions that it was a fact that these people had performed these illegal acts. They were taken by the Greek authorities as fact. This sworn evidence by Detective Inspector Thomas was the prime evidence, if not the only evidence, that was used to charge these people in Greece.

Detective Inspector Thomas was the agent of the Australian Government. He was sent to Greece with all the authority of the Australian Government, to produce this evidence. He produced it under oath, claiming to the Greek authorities that what he was saying was fact. Any reading of the documents that are now available about what happened in Greece can leave only this impression. Therefore the Greek authorities believed that they were dealing with someone who, in giving evidence under oath, was in fact stating facts. The evidence which was given in February 1979, we are told, was given because the police officer was called before an examining magistrate and was required to give on oath an outline of the case to be presented in Australia.

Leaving aside the question of whether Detective Inspector Thomas was called on or whether he offered his testimony, I point out that he was not requested to, and did not, give an outline of the case to be presented in Australia. He was stating under oath that certain things had happened and was giving evidence against these nine people. He was directly connecting them to a case which was proceeding in Sydney-a case which at that time had not been decided, which, I might point out, has not been decided now, and which, in view of the magistrate' s comments last week, may be some way from being decided.
On page 5 Senator Durack states:
Senator Grimes claims that all the evidence against those persons was evidence supplied by Australian Police. The documents themselves do not establish this.

They may not be the only documents. There may be other evidence. I suggest that if other evidence was used in Greece it is up to the Attorney-General to produce it. But in the absence of other evidence and after many months of seeking what evidence was used in Greece, I believe that we have all the evidence. I believe that the documents that are available to me, and, as far as I know, to the Attorney-General, do not present any other evidence. I do not believe that it was the clear understanding of the Australian police officers concerned that the Greek authorities would not institute any proceedings in Greece against these nine persons. I believe that it was the clear understanding of Detective Inspector Thomas and his colleagues that in fact what would happen would be that the Greek authorities would proceed in this way and that he was only too willing to assist them.
On page 5 of the circulated copy of his statement Senator Durack states:

I have reason to believe that the authorities in Greece may be under the impression that it was the wish of the Australian Government that the persons named in the Australian Requests for Assistance should be prosecuted in Greece. If that is the fact then there has been a misunderstanding of the purpose of the Requests for Assistance made by the Australian Government.

I suggest that not only were the Greek authorities taking a reasonable approach when they interpreted the Australian request for assistance, associated as it was with the evidence of Detective Inspector Thomas, but also was there no other reasonable interpretation of what was going on at the time. A request came from the Australian Government naming nine people who had been involved in a conspiracy case along with 183 people in Australia. It was backed up by more detail and definite statements of their guilt by the senior police officer in the case, on oath, who knew at the most basic level that prosecutions along the same line could ensue in Greece; and that is what happened. There was no misunderstanding by the Greek Government. The so-called misunderstanding was a consequence of what I consider to be the misuse of the Australian request for assistance by a police officer at that time. That police officer, of course, is no longer in that police force. He is in legal practice now, while the people who were charged have been either discharged from the case, having suffered from their association with it, or are still, long years later, involved in a protracted court case.

On page 6 of Senator Durack's statement we find that the first action taken by the Australian Government was to make representations on behalf of the three people indemnified in Australia. But the Australian Government took this action in September, four months after the notification of the arrests had appeared in the Australian Press. These people had been given pardons but it took four months for the Government to put pen to paper or to organise a telex. There was no concern about the other people who had been charged, as to whether there had been a misunderstanding of the purpose of the request for assistance, though Greek Australians-most of them are Greek Australians-had been gaoled on the say so of a person who was then a police inspector. The whole matter was allowed to drift by by both the Government and the Attorney-General. We do not believe that this is satisfactory. We made several inquiries when the Parliament resumed in the Budget session. It may be that that is what led to the Australian Government taking the action that it took in September.

In paragraph 11 on page 6 of the printed copy of his speech, Senator Durack makes the point that the conspiracy charges were dropped against 111 defendants charged with conspiracy in Sydney, with no proceedings at all instituted against 38 of them. He then makes what I consider to be an astonishing remark, namely, that as these matters were the subject of considerable publicity he is:
confident that the Greek Embassy in Australia was aware of the developments.

As soon as these charges had been dropped, the Opposition, through me, asked Senator Durack, in this Parliament, about his responsibility to inform the Greek Government because of the relevance of this action to the overseas charges. It seems to me in light of this statement that he, in fact, did not do so.

I very much would like to know what the Attorney sees as his responsibility in such a situation. I suggest that his responsibility was more than to send Press cuttings across to the Greek Embassy or to draw the attention of the Greek Ambassador to what was in the Australian Press. I believe that it was his duty to send the complete statement of his understanding of how this affected the arrest of pensioners in Greece. It was his duty to reverse the so-called ' misunderstanding', as he now calls it, of the Greek Government of the request for assistance. It seems that he did not do so, and I find that extraordinary in these circumstances.

Again, on page 6, in paragraph 12, Senator Durack states that at least six approaches have been made by the Australian Government to the Greek Government or to Greek officials about the proceedings in Greece. I suggest that we need a full account of those proceedings if the Senate is ever to give any credence to Senator Durack's claim that he has taken proper action. One can only assume that his attitude to this matter has been, to say the least, casual. I suggest that the procrastination over answering questions as to what is going on in this case and the fact that we have had to drag information out of the Minister and the Government suggests that they believed that the whole thing would blow away. This case will not blow away in this country or in Greece and we should not allow it to do so. If we look at page 6 of the ministerial statement it seems that this matter was compounded by the fact that, although Senator Durack, as Attorney-General, wrote to the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 23 January and asked for detailed advice as to the state of proceedings in Sydney to be sent to the Greek Government through the Department of Foreign Affairs this was not done . On page 7 of the ministerial statement we find these words:
Due to a misunderstanding by the Department of Foreign Affairs this was not done.

This case is full of misunderstandings. We have the Greek authorities misunderstanding the nature of the request for assistance from the Australian Government and we have the Department of Foreign Affairs in this country misunderstanding something in this regard. So no details were sent from the Attorney-General of this country to the Greek authorities while nine people who were citizens of this country, three of whom had been indemnified, were under charge and in goal in Greece. Whose responsibility is this? I suggest that it is the Government's responsibility. The Government had a responsibility to look after these people who were Australian citizens and who had been residents of this country. The record of this sorry case is that the Government took no interest. On page 7 of this statement we find also these words:
I wrote in June 1981 to the Minister for Justice in Greece about the cases of the three persons who had been indemnified . . .

The Attorney-General referred to the others only in general terms. Not until 25 February 1982, 21 months after the arrests in Athens, did the Crown Solicitor make it clear that the Australian Government did not request proceedings against any of those persons charged in Greece. The alleged misunderstanding happened 21 months earlier but the Government was prepared to allow imprisonment, followed by monthly reporting to the police and fear among the arrested pensioners about what was to happen to them, without lifting a finger to say to the Greek authorities: 'We never intended these arrests to happen. We did not request that these proceedings go ahead'. According to the Attorney-General that was the misunderstanding of the Greek Government-a misunderstanding for which, I suggest , one certainly cannot blame the Greek Government in view of the nature of the request and the manner in which it was made by the police officer.

In November 1981 the Government learnt from unofficial sources that it was to be asked for evidence-an obvious move which I raised when I initially questioned the Attorney-General about this matter. The Government has now informed the Greek Government that it cannot provide such assistance. Nearly two years after the arrests the Government has only now clarified its wish not to get embroiled in the Athens case-it should not be embroiled-and then only after it had decided that it probably would not have proceeded against four of the persons concerned and could not have proceeded against those with indemnities.

I agree with the Attorney-General in hoping that there will be an early and satisfactory conclusion to the proceedings that are going on in Greece. But I suggest that there could have been an earlier and more satisfactory conclusion if it had not been for the half-hearted and casual approach of the Government in this matter. The Attorney-General complained about the difficulty of making the Government's position known to the Greek judicial authorities through the existing lines of communication. We have close associations with Greece. Greek migrants have been coming to Australia since the early part of the last century. We surely have some knowledge about Greek judicial procedures. We surely have lines of communication with Greece, if we have lines of communication with any community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we get through?

—I will tell the honourable senator what has happened. We on the Opposition were so disturbed about what was going on over there that we obtained documents from the Greek courts. We got them out here and had them translated at our expense to find out just what was going on. It was only then that any action was taken. Detective Inspector Thomas had no difficulty in making his position known when he visited Greece with his request for assistance. He ended up in the Greek courts giving evidence on oath stating that certain things had happened in Australia. In this country those same people had been charged but most of them had not been in the courts at all. He went over to Athens twice as the representative of this Government. He went over there and gave totally unsubstantiated evidence under oath in 1978 and 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the Government had all the time in the world to set right the alleged misunderstanding that arose after Detective Inspector Thomas made his statements on oath. The Government sent Detective Inspector Thomas to Greece twice. I believe that it should have sent other officers to Greece twice, particularly officers who could speak Greek and who had some knowledge of the Greek judicial system. There are plenty of Greek-Australian lawyers in this country who have knowledge of that system. The Government simply has not cared, as it had not cared all along in this case. In excess of $7m has been expended on this case in Australia alone. It would have cost only a few thousand dollars more to deal with this so-called misunderstanding by the Greek Government that arrested nine people in Greece. Those people have been in a state of uncertainty ever since. The Australian Government has created great difficulties not only for those nine people but also for other Greek-Australians in Greece who have Australian pensions. When the Minister refers to promoting whatever means are open to us to sort this matter out, I suggest those means should include the despatch of a senior officer to Athens to talk to the Greek authorities, to put the Government's new-found belief that the charges against these people in Greece under Greek law for offences they committed in Australia under Australian law should be dropped.

If the Attorney-General has the clear conscience that he says he has on all of these matters I suggest that he should not object to my request that all the representations that have been made to the Greek authorities on this matter should be tabled in this Parliament. This case has been dragging on since 1978. All the questions raised-I will not put them as accusations-in this Parliament by the Opposition about the conduct of the case in Australia and the conduct of the case in Greece have been initially denied by the authorities in Australia but in every instance they have been demonstrated to be true. I believe that in the long run there will be a proper investigation of what happened from April 1978 until now. In the long run this case will demonstrate that authorities, even under our law, will not be able to discriminate against people in the way in which they have just because they happen to be of a different nationality. The Opposition will not let this matter rest; nor will the Greek-Australian citizens of this country. We will not be fobbed off by statements such as this, well meaning as they may be. I think it is time that the Attorney-General and other people really had a look at the behaviour of the officials and the authorities involved in this case so that we have no repetition of it in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Missen) agreed to:

(1) (a) That a Standing Committee of the Senate, to be known as the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, be appointed to report, in respect of the clauses of Bills introduced into the Senate, and in respect of Acts of the Parliament, whether such Bills or Acts, by express words or otherwise-
(i) trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;
(ii) make rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers;
(iii) make such rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon non- reviewable administrative decisions;
(iv) inappropriately delegate legislative power; or
(v) insufficiently subject the exercise of legislative power to parliamentary scrutiny.

(b) That the Committee, for the purpose of reporting upon the clauses of a Bill when the Bill has been introduced into the Senate, may consider any proposed law or other document or information available to it, notwithstanding that such proposed law, document or information has not been presented to the Senate.
(2) That the Committee have power to consider the Minutes of Evidence and records of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills appointed by Resolution of the Senate of 19 November 1981.

(3) (a) That, unless otherwise ordered, the Committee consist of six Senators, three being members of the Government to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and three being Senators who are not members of the Government, to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators.

(b) That the nominations of the Opposition or any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators be determined by agreement between the Opposition and any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators, and, in the absence of agreement duly notified to the President, the question as to the representation on the Committee be determined by the Senate.
(4) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5) That the quorum of the Committee be three.

(6) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the Bills, Acts or other document or information which the Committee is empowered to consider and that the quorum of a sub-committee be two Senators.
(7) That the Committee elect a Government member as Chairman.

(8) That the Chairman may from time to time appoint a member of the Committee to be Deputy-Chairman and the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(9) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy- Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(10) That a Senator, though not a member of the Committee, may participate in its public sessions and question witnesses, unless the Committee orders otherwise, but shall not vote.

(11) That the Committee or any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to meet and transact business in public or private session and notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.
(12) That, unless otherwise ordered by the Senate, all records and all documents received by the Committee remain in the custody of the Senate.
(13) That members of the public and representatives of the news media may attend and report any public session of the Committee unless the Committee otherwise orders.

(14) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and that a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings of the Committee as take place in public.

(15) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint Counsel to advise the Committee, and other persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee, with the approval of the President.
(16) That the Committee not meet while the Senate is actually sitting, unless by special order of the Senate.

(17) That the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such recommendations as it may deem fit, and be expected to make regular reports as to the progress of the proceedings of the Committee.
(18) That the Committee may authorise the televising of public hearings of the Committee, at the discretion of the Committee, and under such rules as the Senate may adopt.

(19) That this Resolution operate as an Order of the Senate until such time as the Senate may determine the motion for the adoption of the Ninth Report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills appointed by Resolution of the Senate of 19 November 1981 and, contingent upon such adoption, the Report of the Standing Orders Committee on proposed new Standing Order 36AAB may be considered by the Senate.

(20) That, until such time as the membership of the Committee may be determined under this proposed Order, the members of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs be members of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.
(21) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
