TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.

When the Crimes Amendment Bill was before the Senate last year the provisions, as set out in the original Bill, dealing with the enforcement of fines were significantly altered by amendments moved by Senator Evans. At the time I questioned whether the new provisions would be workable. Since then, and before the matter had been dealt with in the House of Representatives, some quite strong complaints were received by me from three State Attorneys-General as to the additional work that would be created for State officers and judicial officers involved in the enforcement of fines imposed for Commonwealth offences and possible confusion due to the different procedures applying to Commonwealth and State matters. I have had it strongly pressed on me that these matters should be considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

In view of this the Government accepted that it would be desirable for the Standing Committee to examine the need for changes in the procedures for the enforcement of fines, both Commonwealth and State, and the form that the procedures should take. I will formally ask the Standing Committee at its next meeting to undertake this task. The object will be to examine whether the existing procedures in the States are adequate, whether any changes in their laws are desirable, having regard of course to the matters that have been the subject of debate in this Parliament. However, that is going to take some time. There are a number of important reforms in this Bill, apart from the enforcement of fines. That was only one aspect of a number of proposed reforms. The Government believes that we should not delay in giving effect to the other reforms in the Bill on which there is widespread agreement in this Parliament and, I think, outside it.

So as to give effect to handling the problem in this way, the Government has moved to delete from the Bill the clauses which had been objected to so strongly by some State Attorneys and with which the Government itself had, on some aspects, some difficulty as well. The Government accepts that the present procedures for enforcement of fines require review to ensure that they are fair and reasonable to those who are affected and also that there ought to be uniformity in these matters throughout Australia. When the Standing Committee of Attorneys has completed the examination of the matter the Government of course will introduce any legislation that may be required to give effect to the Committee's conclusions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose these amendments which have come to us from the House of Representatives but I cannot pretend that we take that stance with any spirit of enthusiasm. The measure, as Senator Durack has said, has had something of a chequered history. When the Bill was originally introduced in the Senate and debated in full on 21 October last year we supported it very strongly, based as it was on an interim report dated January 1980 of the Australian Law Reform Commission on sentencing, because it implemented, at least partially, some of the more urgent recommendations arising out of that report. We were very happy to see on the statute book, and did in fact regard as very long overdue, provisions setting guidelines for judges in the imposition of sentences of imprisonment and a whole series of other provisions facilitating in various ways the imposition of non-custodial sentences for offenders against Federal law.

SPEECH.PARA: When this matter was debated last October we were, however, concerned that some recommendations that were equally as urgent and equally as important as those which the Government had picked up had been omitted from the Bill and we did seek to make certain additions to the Bill to pick up those recommendations in particular in relation to the subject matter of the imposition of gaol terms following default, that is the failure to pay fines which had been imposed. In particular we sought through the addition of proposed new section 18C a provision which was designed to ensure that imprisonment really was the last resort in situations in which an offender originally fixed with a fine proved unable in fact to pay that fine. The nub and substance of the provision, which I understand Senator Haines will have a little more to say about in a moment, essentially was to provide for further flexibility in the courts so that time to pay could be granted where the further interests of justice demanded or suggested it and so that, I repeat, imprisonment really was a last resort.

The amendment that was embodied in proposed new section 18C was essentially fairly small in compass but it did round out the original scheme of the legislation and eventually the Government was persuaded, with a little help from this side and from the Australian Democrats, to that point of view. However, apparently so far as some of the States were concerned this was the straw to break the camel's back. They have reacted in a rather unhappy way, I think, to what they perceive to be the administrative burdens being imposed upon them not only by proposed new section 18C but also by a companion provision, proposed new section 18B which also deals with applications for further time to pay.

It is more in a spirit of sorrow than in anger that I record that the New South Wales Government-a Labor government though it may be-seemed to be the first to make these objections. I might hasten to add that it did not do so on the ground of principle but on the ground of administration because of the burdens which would be imposed upon a hard pressed court system. It was only a matter of time, of course, before other States leapt into the fray following the yodel that emerged from Attorney-General Walker. As I understand it, Queensland and South Australia have been among the more intransigent of those insisting that there are difficulties here that cannot be immediately overcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —New South Wales did not even think that the Commonwealth should take any initiative in criminal law reform.

—Yes. Senator Durack will be pleased to know that States' rights are alive and well even in the most radical of our States. I simply hope, on this as on many other issues, that considerations of national convenience and the interests of the Australian citizens at large will ultimately prevail. The question then became, given these objections, whether the passage of this Bill should in its final form await the further consideration of these matters to which the Attorney-General had adverted. The Attorney-General discussed the matter with me. I was obliged to agree, given the notorious lethargy of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General-not that I am suggesting that the Attorney put the proposition to me in quite those terms-that it would be better to proceed and get on the statute book and into operation those very many parts of the legislation which could have an immediate impact in improving and civilising the standards of criminal justice in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I say further in that respect that I do wish to correct the impression that was given by one of our speakers on this Bill in the House of Representatives that there had been no consultation by the Attorney-General with me as to at least one part of the amendment that now comes back to us. There was some misunderstanding in this respect at a staff level as a result of my own failure, which I readily acknowledge, to fully communicate the substance of the discussion which I had with the Attorney-General. It must be acknowledged that the Attorney has endeavoured to secure the acceptance of the Bill in its original form but has run into dificulties. As a matter of common sense it does seem to be the way to handle the matter; that is, to send the controversial parts of the Bill off to the Standing Committee but not to delay the passage of that which can, in fact, go through. I do hope that we will get a sensible review of this whole question from the Standing Committee. I do hope that we will get a satisfactory solution to this problem. I do hope that the neuroses of various kinds that have been expressed by the States will come to be, after further consideration, assuaged. I do hope that we will have further legislation reincorporating these provisions and perhaps some more like them later this year .

Finally, I note that a further report is due in 1983 from the Australian Law Reform Commission on the balance of its sentencing reference. I suppose we could wait until then-the way this place and the Government tend to operate I fear that it may be that we will wait until then-to get these provisions back into the statute book. I hope that delay does not occur. The law of sentencing is already notoriously piecemeal. That situation has been made worse by the removal from this legislation of some important and central provisions in the scheme of sentencing justice that was there proposed. The lesson-if we can learn any lessons in this area from the performance of the courts and the legislatures in the last several decades-is that sentencing reform cannot really be achieved in a piecemeal way if the objectives of uniformity and consistency, and the policy objective of priority to non-custodial sentences, are to be achieved. I hope that the difficulties that have arisen with this legislation can be resolved by good will and further consultation. It is in that spirit that I indicate-again, as I said, with not much enthusiasm but for the reasons I have outlined-that the Opposition will not oppose these amendments which have the effect of significantly emasculating the Bill in the form in which it left this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Evans has already pointed out , on 21 October last year the Senate passed, among others, several amendments moved by Senator Evans which aimed to amend the Government's Crimes Amendment Bill 1981 to provide that imprisonment did not automatically follow the non- payment of a fine. Instead the court was to have to satisfy itself that 'the offender had the means to pay the fine and wilfully refused to pay it'. Where this was not the case the court could, under proposed section 18C (4), reduce the amount of the fine, give the offender more time to pay or vary the punishment. As Senator Evans has already pointed out, these amendments were supported by the Australian Democrats but not by the Government. They were based on recommendations made by the Australian Law Reform Commission in a substantial interim report which it brought down in January 1980. The report was prepared under the leadership of Mr Justice Kirby, assisted by Professor Duncan Chappell. The report dealt with a large number of matters but specified non-custodial options associated with fining, which is the subject of Senator Evans's amendments, as one of the two most urgent areas of reform. I refer the Senate to page 105 of the interim report which, in paragraph 160 entitled 'De- institutionalisation', states:

SPEECH.PARA: To sentence a person to imprisonment is to order him to be deprived of his liberty by confinement. In our form of society, the deprivation of freedom is one of the severest methods of punishments we can employ. Moreover, it is widely held, and the quotations above reflect this, that imprisonment is in many ways an unsatisfactory form of punishment. This view is shared by the Commission. Neither the history of the use of imprisonment nor contemporary research lends any support to the persistent belief that the use of imprisonment leads to the diminution of crime either by way of deterrence or rehabilitation.

I would imagine that that statement was predominantly behind four of the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission's report, specifically No. 31, which is entitled 'Guidelines for Use of Imprisonment', and Nos 32, 33 and 34 under the heading 'Non-payment of Fines'. Recommendation No. 31 of the Commission states:
A law of the Commonwealth should be enacted specifying the general criteria which a court sentencing a Federal offender shall take into account before imposing a sentence of imprisonment.
Then the report lists three criteria that ought to be considered. Recommendation No. 32 refers to the non-payment of fines and makes the statement:

Where a court is satisfied that an offender has wilfully and without just excuse failed to pay a fine imposed in respect of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth, the court may order that the offender be imprisoned. In all other cases, the court should have the power to extend the time specified for the payment of the fine, to adjust the level of the fine, or award punishment other than imprisonment as is appropriate in the circumstances of the case.
No. 33 goes on to state:

Apart from general criteria, more detailed guidelines are required if the use of imprisonment in Federal cases is to be limited to appropriate circumstances and put on a rational, principled, consistent and uniform basis. Such guidelines should be developed by the Sentencing Council.
Finally, recommendation 34 makes the point:
The so called 'short, sharp shock' use of imprisonment should be discouraged by Commonwealth law.

Yet despite these recommendations the Government chose in the other place to delete the amendments which this chamber had passed. During the Committee stage debate in the other place, the Minister representing the Attorney-General, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, said:

There is a question as to whether the new provisions are workable. Apart from this, strong complaints have been received by the Government from a number of State Attorneys-General as to the additional work that would be created for State officers involved in the enforcement of fines for Commonwealth offences and as to possible confusion and inefficiency due to different procedures applying in Commonwealth and State matters.

So clearly, as Senator Evans has already pointed out, at the first sign of objection from the States-not all of which, I might add, are noted for their reformist zeal or even for their payment of strict attention to the principle of civil liberties-the Federal Government was prepared to back off, leaving yet another area of law reform abandoned. Mr Viner went on to say:

Suggestions have been made that the matter should be considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Having regard to the matters raised by State Attorneys-General, the Government accepts that it would be desirable for the Standing Committee to examine the need for changes in procedures for the enforcement of fines, both Commonwealth and State, and the form that the new procedures should take. Therefore, the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) will ask the Standing Committee to examine this matter.

One is forced to wonder why originally in 1978 the Attorney-General referred the whole question of sentencing Federal offenders to the Law Reform Commission if the Government proposed simply to ignore the recommendations that the Commission made, or send them to yet another standing committee. I agree that some uniformity in the law is desirable, but for the life of me I cannot see why, because one or two States complain, we should immediately retreat to the lowest common denominator. I cannot understand why the Commonwealth cannot accept its responsibility to lead and to implement the work of the Law Reform Commission.

Surely it is time we got away from what appear to be the last vestiges of Dickensian attitudes to incarceration under which, as those honourable senators who have studied any history at all would know, people were tossed into gaol simply because they were poor. Thereby any possibility that they might have of getting themselves out of that predicament was neatly severed. Although at the moment we do not make permanent incarceration for failure to pay a fine, it is nonethless absurd that gaol is seen as an alternative at all unless-as was made a specific exception under the clause-failure to pay is wilful. I appreciate that the Senate does not need a lecture from me or anybody else on the failure of the penal system to rehabilitate criminals, or the tendency of a period in goal, however short, to harden rather than diminish the anti-social attitudes of wrong-doers, particularly of the young. The Law Reform Comission has devoted a considerable amount of space in the interim report to canvassing just that issue . So I am at a loss to understand not only why the Government cannot see its way clear to offer a reformist lead to the States but also why the Opposition is not pursuing the matter. I would have thought that it warranted more than simply an expression in another place by Mr Lionel Bowen of disappointment on the part of the Australian Labor Party that the Government was not prepared to accede to the amendments that had been passed in the Senate. I repeat, the Australian Democrats supported the principle behind the amendments last year and, indeed, do so again. Unfortunately, the five of us are powerless to implement anything at all in this place without the support of one of the other major parties, so there is precious little point in our pursuing the amendments that were deleted in another place. All I intend to do at the moment is indicate that we do not accept that the provisions made under the amendments are 'not workable'. We do accept the need for the amendments, as they stand, in a spirit of law reform and simple humanitarianism. Finally, we ask that the Minister move expeditiously to refer the matter to a Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and hope, with some justification we trust, that that Committee will do its work as quickly as possible and make suitable recommendations for changes in the law.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I understood that the Government was to suggest a cognate debate on Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 and Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1982. Is that correct?
—The Government agrees to that course being followed.

—Then the debate will cover those two measures. Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides, under certain conditions, for access to Australian Taxation Office income records of individuals for the purpose of law enforcement and extends access to those records to an additional government department. The Department referred to in the Bill is the former Department of Housing and Construction. I am not sure what procedures are required following the dismemberment of that Department which has taken place since the Bill was passed by the House of Representatives. I do not know whether it is necessary to move a minor amendment to change the wording or whether it can be done by regulation. Whatever the outcome, the section of the bureaucracy which has replaced the Department of Housing and Construction will have access to tax records of individuals for the purpose of administering the taxation rebate for people who fairly recently took out the housing loans which were provided as an election stunt just before the Victorian elections.

SPEECH.PARA: Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3), in its original form, did no more than exempt the company Australian Wool Testing Authority Ltd, which is to be established, from income taxation. But on 6 May the Government added to the Bill an amendment which was actually relevant to access to confidential records of the Australian Taxation Office and therefore ought to have been included in Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2). However, that Bill had been passed in the House of Representatives on the previous night. The amendment made to Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3) was, in fact, suggested by the Opposition. It restricted access to confidential taxation records to circumstances in which there was reason to believe that the person concerned was guilty of a crime punishable by six months' imprisonment or more. The Opposition also sought in the House of Representatives to require the approval of both Houses of the Parliament before law enforcement officers would have access to confidential taxation records. That section of the proposed amendment was not accepted by the Government, but subsequently will be moved by Senator Evans at the Committee stage in the Senate. I repeat, the Bill includes part of a proposed amendment which stipulated the conditions under which access to the confidential records of individuals would be made available. Again, I say that that provision ought to have been a part of Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2). The Opposition will seek to amend further Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3).

This untidy and, I must say, highly confusing procedure, is a function of the indecent haste with which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wound up the House of Representatives in the first week of May. He was, of course, eager to take off on the tourist circuit yet again. The Prime Minister was also fearful of keeping the Parliament sitting when it could be closed down, because a sitting parliament provides a forum for the ventilation of contemporary scandals , to which this Government is extraordinarily prone. We saw in the Senate today yet another example of the way in which the Parliament can be used to ventilate scandals involving senior Ministers of this Government and to extract information which would not be likely to be extracted if Parliament were not sitting. The Government, of course, had it had the numbers, would have closed down the Senate by now. Therefore, the disclosures pertaining to the misuse of Reserve Bank of Australia money by certain dairy companies and further evidence of maladministration in this industry, for which Mr Nixon is responsible, would not have been disclosed if the Government had had its way.

I do not intend to speak at length on the access to confidential information requirements of Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982. The purpose of the amendments is partly to clamp down on tax dodging. Indeed, it was prompted by the requests or urgings from the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and by the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. But as well as being a minor weapon in the arsenal opposing the anti-tax dodging arsenal, more importantly perhaps the intention of the amendment is to give law enforcement officers access to personal tax records in the belief that such information will help to secure convictions for offences not related to breaches of the taxation law.

As I said, as far as the tax avoidance or tax dodging elimination content is concerned, it is a very minor weapon. The crucial weapon to be used in any effective crackdown on tax avoidance is, of course, the credible threat of retrospective legislation, which is a policy that the Australian Labor Party alone, of all the political groups represented in this Parliament, has. Only the Labor Party is serious about stamping out tax evasion and tax avoidance. Therefore, only the Labor Party can secure the substantial tax reductions for all honest taxpayers which would be made possible by an effective crackdown on tax avoidance. After a Labor government is elected some time in the next 18 months, I eagerly anticipate the first piece of legislation being introduced into the Senate to do just that; that is, to crack down on anti-social tax avoidance. In advance, I throw down the challenge to whichever members of the Australian Democrats may still be in the Parliament at that time and to Senator Harradine who, barring double dissolutions, will still be in the Parliament at that time, either to support that legislation or to face a double dissolution election arising from it. I cannot think of any issue on which I would be happier to fight a double dissolution election against the ditherers in this Parliament than legislation to crackdown on tax avoidance in the only way in which it can effectively be done and in the simplest way in which it can be done .

The second part of the Income Tax Assessment Bill (No. 2), as I mentioned earlier, implements the Government's policy on tax rebates for certain classes of people who have housing loans. This was announced in a sort of desperate last -minute bid to save the Liberal Government of Victoria from the crushing defeat which it subsequently suffered. It provides for a rebate of $500 to a couple in the first year after a housing loan has been taken out. This is reduced by $100 in each of the next four succeeding years. If the couple in question have children, an additional $200 is added to the tax rebate for which the couple, or the principal taxpayer, will qualify.

The Opposition does not oppose that provision, but it would be remiss of me if I failed to mention that, welcome no doubt though that pittance may be to a limited number of people who hold housing loans, it falls very far short of compensating for the massive increases in interest rates which have occurred under this Government in the last couple of years. I cite some specific examples . If a loan for $40,000 were taken out in March 1980, the increases in interest rates which have occurred since that time would have added more than $21 more to the repayments than will be provided by this Bill. That applies to a couple without children. A couple with dependent children who took out a loan of $40, 000 in March 1980, even after the adjustment for the rebate provided for in this bill, will be worse off by over $17 a week because of the massive increases in interest rates that have occurred in that two-year or 26-month period. A couple who took out a loan for the same amount, $40,000, in March 1981, after adjustment for this rebate and for increases in interest rates, will be more than $6 a week worse off. A couple who took out a loan of $40,000 14 months ago, after the necessary adjustments have been made, will still be $2.30 a week worse off. So, this Bill provides for almost nobody complete compensation for the massive increase in interest rates of the last couple of years and the consequential increase in monthly housing loan repayments. On behalf of the Opposition I now move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2):
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(a) the Bill contains insufficient safeguards to ensure that access to tax records is not abused, and-
I interpolate that appropriate amendments will be moved in the Committee stage, by Senator Evans and not by me. The amendment to the motion for the second reading continues:
(b) the Bill fails to provide adequate compensation to Australian home buyers for the massive increase in interest repayments over the last 2 years'.

I have demonstrated the evidence to support the second proposition. I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1982, but I understand that, procedurally, that should be done at a later stage. That Bill contains an amendment, which was added as an afterthought by the Government, stipulating the conditions under which access to private taxation records will be made available to law enforcement officers. Disregarding that, it is a Bill to provide the Australian Wool Testing Authority Ltd with exemption from income tax. It is a Bill that takes us right back to the razor gang farce of 30 April last year. The razor gang exercise was Malcolm Fraser's 1981 stunt to divert attention from the sorry mess his Government had made of the Australian economy, and of Australian society. Of course the 1982 stunt was the grand plan for world economic recovery, launched a couple of weeks ago when the Prime Minister of Australia, who is shown by the objective statistical record to be one of the dunces in the class of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, promoted himself to lecturer.

Even allowing for the fact that the razor gang exercise of last year was primarily a stunt with a few silly decisions tacked on to it, this particular decision was almost unbelievably stupid. It was a decision to sell off to the private sector, so the Government said, the Australian Wool Testing Authority which had operated for some 25 years as a subsidiary initially of the Australian Wool Board and later of the Australian Wool Corporation, both of which were statutory authorities. The Australian Wool Testing Authority provided objective tests of clean wool content, average fibre diameter, vegetable fault and a number of other characteristics of wool quality which determine its commercial value and which can be objectively measured. It was an organisation with an unquestioned reputation for technical competence and integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it was profitable.

—Yes, it was profitable. In spite of keeping its charges low, it covered its costs completely and even showed a small profit, which was returned to the Corporation. Into this highly efficient scene intruded the clumsy marauders of the razor gang. I will not quote what various Australian Labor Party people may have said about this; I would rather quote what the Liberal Party member for Canning (Mr Bungey) has said about it.
—He is from Western Australia.

—Yes, he is. He is a former wool grower. He is probably still a wool producer but I am not certain of that. He was active in farmer politics and I think it would be fair to say that he was fairly well respected in farmer politics as at least being a man with a keen mind. I will refer to some of his references to this matter. On 14 May last year, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of farmer organisations and a number of branches of the Liberal Party of Australia which are aware of country problems--
Unlike the clumsy marauders of the razor gang-
have opposed the proposal to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority.
By 4 June last year he had toughened his attitude up a bit and, in relation to the razor gang decision to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority, said:

I can assure honourable members that there was no consultation-I have checked on this very closely-with the Australian Wool Council, which has followed on from the Australian Wool Industry Conference.
That is, the grower organisation. He continued:
There was very little, if any, discussion with the Australian Wool Corporation.

When the Bill now before the Senate was being passed by the House of Representatives on 6 May this year Mr Bungey spoke very briefly on the Bill's second reading and expressed his opposition to it, on these grounds:

First, I believe tax exemption to a private company is completely undesirable. It sets a precedent which should not be set . . . My second reason for opposing both the Bill and the amendment is that the present wool testing arrangements are more than satisfactory and no change is required. Thirdly, additional wool testing costs will be imposed on wool growers because of the cosmetic changes proposed by this legislation.

I think Mr Bungey raised a valid point when he said that the precedent of granting tax exemption to what is supposed to be a private company is a bad precedent to set. But of course in no sense is the Australian Wool Testing Authority Ltd a private company except in the cosmetic sense. It is a fiction; it is a cosmetic edifice constructed to hide the embarrassment of this Government for having been stupid enough to accept the recommendations of the razor gang in the first place. This legislation is a farce and although I have some sympathy with Mr Bungey's view that the precedent of tax exemption for a private company, or a cosmetically private company, is a precedent that should not be set, the opposition will not oppose the Bill to grant it tax exemption because it should not have been a private company and in no sense, other than in the most technical legal sense, is it a private company now.

The razor gang in general and this decision in particular reflect very badly on the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, and the Minister for Finance, Senator Guilfoyle, both of whom were members of the razor gang committee. This decision demonstrates perhaps more clearly than any other single decision the sloth and negligence with which they approached their task, their ignorance of the subject matter with which they were dealing and their irresponsibility in making such recommendations. The reason for the recommendation appears to have been that the Government thought it could liquidate the Authority and claim its assets of $12m or thereabouts. It then found that it could not do that. Does that not tell us a great deal about the sloth and negligence with which these two Ministers and others approached their task? The Government, having found that it could not collect the $12m which it thought it could, did not do the sensible thing and drop the whole silly proposal but stumbled and fumbled along for a full year and then produced this cosmetic and completely unnecessary piece of legislation. Hence we go through this charade today.

It is ironic that Senator Guilfoyle, who assiduously promotes the idea that she is extremely competent, has lying around so many monuments to her incompetence. The notorious Greek social security conspiracy case, which was the subject of a statement earlier today by Senator Grimes, which has cost the taxpayers of Australia more than $7m and which has caused a great deal of anguish to a number of innocent people living in Australia and overseas, is one of the monuments to Senator Guilfoyle's competence. As Minister for Social Security, she initiated that case and those unsuccessful prosecutions. As Minister for Social Security, she also presided over the substitution of an income test for the means test for pensions in 1976. The Government has spent the last five years trying to work out how to get itself out of that hole.

In a debate in the Senate on 18 November last year, Senator Guilfoyle authoritatively stated that it was essential for primary producers to even out their taxable incomes through the use of income equalisation deposits in order to avoid the tax penalty which would otherwise be applied. By stabilising taxable income in that way, they incur a penalty; they do not avoid it. She is supposed to be one of the competent Ministers of this Government. The mind boggles at what the incompetent Ministers must be like. Far from being correct, she was precisely incorrect. The truth was the complete opposite of what she had asserted.

Then, of course, as Senator Guilfoyle's crowning glory, we had her participation as a key member of the razor gang committee which produced this stupid recommendation to sell off an efficient body operating without causing any trouble to anyone and, consequently, the charade of this silly and unnecessary piece of legislation in the Senate this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) and Income Tax Assessment (Amendment) Bill (No. 3) which, between them, seek to do three things. They seek, first, to give royal commissions and, through them, the Attorney-General's Department-and through that Department, the Australian Federal Police-access to certain tax records of people who the Commissioners believe may have committed serious crimes. Secondly , these Bills attempt to implement the Government's housing package, which was announced shortly before the Victorian election. Thirdly, these Bills seek to change the title of the Australian Wool Testing Authority to the Australian Wool Testing Authority Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats support both of these Bills. We have reservations about them, in that in many areas they do not go anywhere near far enough. But it is vital that both of these Bills receive a speedy passage. The Labor Party has just circulated in this chamber three sets of amendments-two sets to be moved at the second reading stage and a third set to be moved in Committee. I have sat here in absolute amazement listening to Senator Walsh accuse the Democrats and Senator Harradine of being soft on tax evaders. At the same time, he is prepared to move in this chamber an amemdment in Committee on these two Bills which, if passed-if the Democrats supported the Labor amendment in Committee-would delay the Bills at least until the Budget session. We are not prepared to do that.

We are also not prepared to support Labor's amendments to the second reading stage, although these are in a form which if agreed to would not delay the Bill. They request two quite separate things. Firstly, they raise the point that the Australian Wool Testing Authority should not receive tax exemption. I shall speak on that subject at length, but I believe that that is a fairly minor matter. More importantly, the amendments cover two other aspects which, as far as we can see, are in conflict.

We believe that insofar as the legislation affects the secrecy provisions of income tax, it has already been amended by the Government in Committee in the Lower House. I shall explain that in greater detail later. We believe that in the Government's help to the housing industry and its rebate on housing interest rates it has not gone far enough, but at least it has made a start.

I come now to the three provisions of these two amending Bills in detail. Firstly, as to the provision that addresses itself to interest rates on home loans, we commend the Government for initiating the rebate scheme for housing, but it has not gone anywhere near far enough. The effect of sky-rocketing interest rates is placing an appalling burden on the section of the community that this Government, or any government, should seek first to protect, and should go out of its way to protect. I refer to the family unit, to the single income family, that is seeking to build a house and start a family. Sky- rocketing interest rates have caused enormous hardships to this section of the community. The Government's initiative through the rebate scheme only touches the sides of the problem. It does not address the basic issue. A one per cent increase in interest rates effectively raises mortgage repayments by 7 per cent. This is the basic problem. The Government must attack high interest rates overall if the economy is to be revived and if the burden placed on the family is to be alleviated.

Although the Democrats support the initiative as far as it has gone, we are committed to an entirely different approach to housing and the management of interest rates. But we shall support this package as a step on the road to recovery and alleviating the problems of hard pressed home owners and future home buyers. My colleague, Senator Haines, will elaborate at much greater length on the problems of sky-rocketing home loan interest rates when the other parts of the Government's package are introduced into the Senate.

I now turn now to the secrecy provisions of the income tax legislation. The Government's response to the request of the Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in relation to access to taxation records must be welcomed. The means by which these Bills were passed in the House of Representatives and the means by which certain amendments were covered deserve some comment. The Labor Party raised the question of confidentiality and the Government took this aboard. As I understand it, amendments were moved to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3), which deals with the question of the Australian Wool Testing Authority, amendments which related to secrecy of income tax information.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government picked up one of the Labor amendments.

—The Government picked up one of the Labor amendments, and we now believe that the question of secrecy has been covered adequately. I must express wonderment at the ingenuity of whoever thought of this idea. Perhaps honourable senators will forgive me if I express hope that it does not become a regular practice of this Government to amend Acts by amending Bills to amend amending Bills. Essentially, that is what happened. If we are all a little confused, that is the reason. Under the provisions of these Bills the Attorney- General may not now disclose information he may be given by a royal commission except for the purposes of communicating it to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police who is then subject to the secrecy requirements. Rather curiously-at least on its face value-such information communicated to the Australian Federal Police in accordance with the provision of the Act cannot be used in court proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: The intention clearly is to alert Federal Police to some wrong doing and to leave it to them to try to catch the criminals. We point out that this is at least a start, although it should be noted that many other countries that cherish democratic principles as much as we do in Australia have seen fit to allow their governments to give tax information to their police forces and to co -operate very closely with police in the fight against organised crime. Most honourable senators will be aware that the infamous criminal Al Capone was eventually arrested, tried and convicted of tax evasion-simply that and nothing else-because no other charge laid against him would stick. It seems to us to be a travesty that in Australia the community cannot be assured that Australian Al Capones will not be dealt with similarly. In other words, we believe there is a lot of room for further investigation by the Government into this matter of co- operation between the Taxation Office and the Federal Police.

One way in which this would be achieved-I put it to the Senate now as a suggestion-would be by swearing in a small number of Treasury agents with special police powers. Recent comments by the Commissioner of Taxation to the effect that he was not prepared to order his officers into a situation in which their lives could be placed in jeopardy highlighted the difficulty that currently exists. Police cannot get tax information which may lead to the conviction of criminals of all sorts. Tax agents are not equipped to operate as policemen. One possibility would be to set up a small squad. For lack of a better name we could call its members Treasury police. These people would be Treasury agents with at least some police powers. However the Government addresses itself to this problem we believe there is an urgent need for greater co-operation between the Department of the Treasury and the Australian Federal Police. Australian Al Capones can be dealt with effectively by no other means.

These two Bills also relate to the Wool Testing Authority. Senator Walsh dealt with this matter at some length. I must say that on this occasion I agree with him entirely. The Government has turned a complete 180 degrees, without any doubt. The razor gang said that we can do without a Wool Testing Authority or, at least, that it would get rid of it to private enterprise. This obviously was an ill-conceived initiative because the Government very quickly found out, firstly, that it was not sure that in fact it owned the Wool Testing Authority and, secondly, that the vital work the Authority is doing-Senator Mason talked of this at length at the time-should not be put in jeopardy. The Government in effect has reversed its decision in this matter by what is purely a device. It has called the Wool Testing Authority a publicly-owned authority by putting the word 'Limited' at the end of its name. It is a device only, because the Government has found that it is necessary to exempt the Authority from income tax if it is to operate effectively. In other words, as far as we can ascertain, it will be getting back to entirely the same operating mode that it previously operated under. If we look at it in detail, we see that there is essentially no change. The Government has gone back to where it started. I can only hope in passing that some of the other initiatives of the Government, the razor gang initiatives, are similarly dealt with; that is, that they are reversed. I refer particularly to the proposal to sell the Government Ordnance Factory at Bendigo.

The Government still has not made clear what it intends to do in these important areas where large numbers of people are employed and where there is a tremendous body of evidence to support the fact that these government factories and authorities have been operating with remarkable efficiency. It is placing a tremendous burden on the employees of these establishments. Under no circumstances do we wish to delay the Government's initiative on the Wool Testing Authority. We hope that in the Budget session, or sooner, the Government will quickly make its position clear in regard to the Government Ordnance Factory at Bendigo and the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg, to name just two.

The Democrats support these Bills, no matter how tortuously they seek to achieve their objects. We wish them a speedy passage. The fight against organised crime has gone on far too long to be handicapped by the Government having one hand tied behind its back. At least by these Bills the bonds have been cut. We now have to tackle the job of determining how the heavy boxing gloves will be used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support much of what is contained in these tax amendment Bills but will make some serious reservations in relation to certain matters which were brought to the attention of the Government by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in regard to some proposals which have been taken up by the Australian Labor Party in the amendments which have been circulated. The Bills before us deal, amongst other things, with overriding those provisions of the tax laws which embody the traditional integrity and secrecy of dealings between the Commissioner of Taxation and those liable to pay tax. The Bills also deal with the implementation of the Government's housing interest rebate scheme and, finally, provide tax immunity for the Australian Wool Testing Authority as now constituted. I would like to make some comments on all of those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The first matter is the attempt by the Government within this legislation to override those secrecy provisions which traditionally have been regarded as so important in Australia, that is, the protection of the confidentiality of communications and assessments by the Commissioner of Taxation with regard to those liable to pay tax. The Government, in attempting to override these provisions, is indeed responding to a very real concern within the community. I do not imagine that any honourable senator or any person within the Australian community would not be prepared to say that these secrecy provisions should not be overidden in those cases where clearly the information that could be obtained from tax records would be of assistance to a royal commission nominated by this Parliament. It is quite clear, as Senator Siddons said, that in Australia we do not have the advantages which have long existed in the United States where the Internal Revenue Service has played a very vital role in combating organised crime.

Insofar as this Bill makes some step, very guarded as it ought to be, towards enabling in certain circumstances tax records and information obtained by the Commissioner of Taxation to be made available to royal commissions looking into those matters which are of dire concern to the community, such as allegations of intimidatory or fraudulent practices in relation to the waterfront of Australia or the circulating of death-dealing drugs within our community-those drugs which damage particularly young Australian lives by undermining their mental or physical health or indeed lead to their early deaths-I will not suppose there is anybody in the Australian community who would not say that a commission ought to have available to it as much information as is possible to enable it to target on those who are responsible for the malpractices in relation to employment in the great waterfront industry in Australia, which is so vital to our survival as a trading nation or in relation to the circulation of such death-dealing drugs. But this Bill goes further than that and would enable the Government, by merely putting into the terms of reference of any royal commission that it ought to have access to these records, to give a right to such access. In that regard the Australian Labor Party is implacably opposed to the general extension of this right of access to all royal commissions. This is entirely out of harmony with the second reading speech of the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown). He said:
It bears repeating that these amendments do not evidence any policy of generally easing the strict confidentiality applying to tax records.

It is quite clear that not only could the Government write in such terms of reference to those of a royal commission inquiring into some quite narrow area of Australian life but also it could write such terms of reference into those of a royal commission perhaps set up as a crimes commission-which has been proposed quite widely over the last few months, and with a degree of community support- which could operate for years and have a more or less continuous existence with the powers of a royal commission without the Parliament ever setting the terms of reference and without the Parliament monitoring or putting under surveillance its continued operation within those terms of reference. In that regard the Labor Party and indeed the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills see some dangers. I think it is important to bring to the attention of honourable senators the fact that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, which was established by this very chamber in order to alert it to the possibility that some legislation might pass through this place with a desirable social objective , on which we could all agree, but with means which unduly trespass on personal liberties, had this to say concerning the matter to which I am drawing attention :

the proposed sub-paragraph . . . would enable any future, unspecified Royal Commission to gain access to information by declaration of the Governor-General, without Parliamentary intervention or scrutiny.

It is one thing to give the two existing commissions-the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking-these powers, named as they are, in the paragraphs of the Bill. I notice Senator Walters paying particular attention to this point. She was a very active member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in coming to this conclusion; that in this provision, rather than naming the two royal commissions we have given to the Government a power to make tax records available to royal commissions whatever their area of scrutiny or inquiry and for however long or continuously they might be in existence. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said this:

While the Committee would not regard the conferral of access to information on future Royal Commissions as necessarily required by Act of Parliament, it suggests that some form of Parliamentary control, whether by affirmative resolution of the Houses or the disallowance procedure, may be worthy of consideration.

As I say, the Labor Party has taken up that point and said that in its view if a royal commission is to be given access to tax records it ought to be by affirmative resolution of the Houses of the Parliament and not simply by Executive act. Let us face it, it could be the case that some royal commissions could be established with a very narrow range of inquiry or, indeed, for purely political purposes in order to embarrass some individual or some institution within our society. In that case we, as the elected representatives, ought to take it upon ourselves to say publicly in this forum that we think the matter is important enough to require that that royal commission have access to tax records which is, after all, to breach a long-standing provision and understanding within our laws. That is not the case and I would hope that the Government sees fit at some stage during the evening to indicate that it will agree with the concern expressed by the scrutiny of Bills Committee, which has as its main function the role of alerting senators to the fact that whilst we have a desirable social objective, it should be pursued by means which are appropriate and it is not appropriate to hand over that power to the Executive, to the Governor-General. It ought to be a power exercised by the elected representatives themselves.

The second part of the legislation before us deals with the Government's implementation of its promise earlier this year to make provision for a rebate of tax for home loan interest payments made on or after 1 July 1982. This is another part of the generally depressing policy pursued by this Government in relation to housing. In fact, one wonders how seriously one can take the Government in relation to housing for Australians when within the last week or two the Government has dismantled the ministry for housing. It is a measure of the concern of this Government that there is no longer within the Australian ministry a Minister who is devoted solely to the question of fulfilling, in a socially just way, the housing needs of Australians. And who can say that those needs are not multiplying day by day, week by week, as ordinary Australians reel under the impact of Government decisions, particularly in relation to interest rates. What sort of government is it which comes into this place with a measure to do with housing without a housing Minister, without anyone to express concern , for example, about the fact that 270,000 Australians live in caravans, mobile homes as they are euphemistically called. Seventy per cent of the caravan dwellers in Melbourne-and I see the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) taking a note of this terrible indictment of the Government which he represents in this place-are long term residents in these caravan parks. They are in a very uneasy state of mind. These caravan parks have emerged as last resort housing for those households without choice, particularly young households, who are forced to move out of their parents homes or who cannot afford rented accommodation.

I will confine my remarks, given the time limits, to the Bill before us which, as I say, deals with a tax rebate for home loan interest payments. Of course, it is a totally inadequate scheme. The fact is that only some 10 per cent of all households will get anything from this particular scheme. Only some 30 per cent of first home buyers will be able to benefit from it. It seems to me that, whilst the Government will make much of this tax rebate scheme, one has to remember that it was introduced as part of a package, a package which included by government agreement with the banks, those immensely profitable institutions, that they ought to be allowed to raise their interest rates by yet another one per cent. In the four years from 1978 to 1982 there has been a tremendous increase from 9.5 per cent to 13.5 per cent in the interest rates on home loans, which has crippled many households and led to much of the social breakdown which is a feature of Australian society, as families find that they are at each other 's throats because of their inability to find that disposable income with which they ought to be able to pay, not for luxury items such as colour television sets, for example, but for those items which are essential to ordinary home and family life. Senator Messner smiles as though he is thinking: 'Senator Tate is on yet another piece of rhetoric rather than dealing with the real facts'. Let me quote from an article in the Sydney Sun Herald of 5 July 1981. It is entitled 'A Couple Losing the Battle'. I am sure that listeners to this parliamentary broadcast will recognise in this case a family living in their own street. This is not an isolated instance. The article states:
Maree and Robert Dobson of Saratoga, near Gosford (NSW), are a young couple battling to stay ahead of rising interest rates.
They started repaying their $30,000 building society loan 12 months ago. Since then the interest rate has risen 2 per cent and their payments have climbed from $306 to $330 a month.
'The repayments have gone up $20 a month while my husband's wage has risen by only $5 a week and mine by $6 . . . Maree said.
Both are trying to earn incomes to keep the household together. Their household wages have risen by $11 a month and their repayments have gone up by $20 a month . Maree is reported as having said:
If I was at home expecting a baby or raising a family there is no way we could afford it.

That is certainly the case in many households around Australia. In my area of Tasmania, for example, I know of the distress caused to many families in Burnie and in surrounding townships when the Burnie pulp mill was forced by market conditions to dismiss a certain number of employees, many of whom had given many years of service and had expected to continue in employment in that mill. Of course, with interest rates as high as they are, any temporary unemployment difficulty, let alone a prolonged one, has a savage impact on the family concerned. A well known community figure of the north west coast, Mr Steve Daly, put it to the Federal Government some weeks ago that as retrenchments, coupled with these high interest rates, were causing such social distress in Burnie the Government ought to make available, to alleviate the distress of those families, some of those moneys which it promised would be available to alleviate the impact of that one per cent rise in interest rates. I made an inquiry, on behalf of Mr Steve Daly, of the then Minister for Housing and Construction. I received a reply from his private secretary which stated:

I can provide no advice on how assistance can be given other than to suggest that such people seek the co-operation of their lending authority and endeavour to secure financial and material support from local charities.

That is the situation. The portfolio of the then Minister for Housing and Construction is now demolished and dismantled. It does not exist any more, so one cannot even turn to the Minister and receive the sort of reply that I received on 27 April 1982. The response of the Government on that date, only a few weeks ago, was to suggest that the person go to the banker or to charitable institutions. But the Federal Government, despite the fact that it said it would try to give assistance to those who were reeling under the impact of high interest rates, had no particular response to give.

I finally and very briefly deal with the Australian Wool Testing Authority. I have had an interest in this matter because it was on behalf of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association that I asked a question of Senator Chaney in this place almost a year ago today. I asked:
Is it a fact that the Government's decision to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority has been overwhelmingly rejected by woolgrowers throughout Australia?
Senator Chaney replied, in part, in his usual whimsical way:
Some of that response has been in negative terms.

It certainly was negative. For example, all the major wool testing and wool brokerage authorities throughout Australia came to the same conclusion; namely, that the Government had acted for purely ideological reasons, with no regard for the impeccable integrity, internationally won, which that authority enjoyed, or for the fact that it was operating efficiently and, indeed, profitably. The Wool Council of Australia-Senator Andrew Thomas, Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, himself a well known authority on merino wool, is nodding in agreement-requested the Government to reconsider its decision in relation to the demolition of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. He acknowledges at least that that plea was put by the leading council of the wool growers of Australia even if he does not acknowledge its care. I am pleased to say that, with the political weight of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats in this place, the Government has acceded to that plea. It has now created a situation where the Australian Wool Testing Authority will enjoy tax free status. That is the purpose of the Bill before us.

The rural community has been served in this place by the Australian Labor Party and by the Democrats and has not been well served by those in the electorate who consistently claim to understand best the interests of the rural producers of Australia. For example, Mr John Kerin, the shadow spokesman for the Australian Labor Party on primary industry matters, enjoys a very high reputation. Even during this winter recess, as he moves around Australia visiting the various councils of rural organisations, farmers and graziers associations and so on, he continues to enhance his reputation as a man who well understands and fights for the interests of the rural industries of Australia. Given the time constraints I will bring my remarks in relation to this Bill to an end. I will probably have a little to say in the Committee stage.

(a) the Bill contains insufficient safeguards to ensure that access to tax records is not abused, and

I have grave reservations on the question of allowing royal commissions to have the sort of power envisaged. I believe, as does Senator Tate, that this is a foot in the door. It is something about which we should be very careful.

I am concerned about the Government bringing forward this legislation, as it has been amended in the House of Representatives, in such a fashion as to put the gun at the head of the Senate and say: 'If you do not pass it in its pristine form there will be delays in ensuring that entitlements flow to taxpayers'. If we were to succumb to that sort of pressure by the Government we would be throwing away our role as a House of review. We are presented with this sort of gun at the head attitude by the Government in respect of the Fertilizers (Subsidy) Amendment Bill 1982, the Home Deposit Assistance Bill 1982 and the Homes Savings Grant Acts Amendment Bill 1982. The Government is saying to us: ' Take it or leave it: The House of Representatives has made amendments to these pieces of legislation. If we amend them, they will have to wait until August before they can go back to that House'.

If we allow ourselves to be subject to this sort of intimidation by the House of Representatives or by the Government, I again say that we are abandoning our role as a House of review. TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they can. They could be brought back next week, if necessary.

—Yes, they can, but with difficulty. If the Government wants them to come back, that can happen. That is another reason why the Senate should not be subjected to any Minister getting up in this place and saying that, unless we pass these Bills, there will be a delay in their implementation until August. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had intended to speak only at the Committee stage in respect of these Bills but I understand that it will suit the convenience of at least one senator who is presently immersed in the basement studio of the Australian Broadcasting Commission if the vote on the motion for the second reading is delayed for a few minutes. Accordingly, I will say now what I otherwise would have said at the Committee stage. I hasten to reassure any honourable senator who might fear that my notorious garrulousness will get the better of me and that this is more of a warm-up for another similar burst in the Committee stage that that will not happen. My moving of the amendment at the Committee stage will be purely formal.

SPEECH.PARA: I address my remarks in foreshadowing the Opposition's amendment purely to the area of and purely as it relates to the question of access to tax records. The relevant changes to the law which are effected by these Bills will alter the secrecy provisions, as we know, of the Income Tax Assessment Act to enable access to tax records by the existing Stewart and Costigan royal comissions on drug trafficking and the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union respectively and also to extend that power of access to future royal commissions which have appropriate terms of reference.

The Opposition supports the extension of the powers of royal commissions to enable access to tax records, certainly in respect of the Stewart and Costigan royal commissions, and sees advantages for this extension as a matter of general principle in the area of organised crime and similarly significant offences that we are talking about. But we do not reach that position of support lightly and we certainly have very grave reservations about the way in which this whole area has now been so broadly opened up by this legislation. The support for the principle of access to tax records is, I think, forced upon us, like any other group of reasonable Australians, by the revelations of the Costigan and Stewart royal commissions and the very powerful argument that emerges particularly from the interim report of the Costigan Commission as ot the utility of access to tax records in conducting investigations into high crimes and misdemeanours involving corporate manipulation, tax fraud and evasion, official corruption and matters of that kind.

The justification for access to tax records in this context is not that, as it is sometimes assumed, your average crook around the place is in the habit of concealing his activities from everyone in the world but comes to be overcome with a fit of penitence and accessibility when it comes to communications with the Commissioner of Taxation. There is an awful lot of nonsense talked about this, about the way in which everyone from your friendly neighbourhood brothel keeper up is in the habit of supplying fair, full and accurate returns to the Commissioner of Taxation in a way that they would not dream of doing were they asked these questions by anyone else. Of course, that is palpable nonsense.

The utility of access to tax records is not in order to enable the law enforcement authorities or anyone else to go simply to the disclosure of illicitly received income and to nab persons accordingly-out of their own mouths or from their own pens-but rather to use the network of data and information that can appear thus in the tax records to develop a much better picture of what is going on in some very complicated criminal transactions. This was put very nicely and simply by the Williams Royal Commission at page 372 of its report in the following terms when it referred to the kind of data which can thus be picked up.

Discrepancies between the income which can possibly be earned from a disclosed legitimate source and the income actually enjoyed and manifest in accumulated assets and lifestyle may indicate the nature and extent of a criminal activity related to--
In this case the example given was of drug trafficking. The report goes on:

Material contained in a return . . . may indicate sources of funds, lines of communications and associations, and open other lines of inquiry by, for example , identifying such things as bank accounts and similar matters.

It is evident that by putting together material of that kind the work of these commissions and inquiries and the work of law enforcement agencies can be much enhanced. Indeed, one could put it more strongly than that. To use the words of Mr Commissioner Costigan in his interim report which was tabled early this year:
It seems to me a scandalous waste of time and money for the Taxation Commissioner not to supply information to the Commission in areas of common interest.

The Opposition accepts that. We think that the argument is made out for access to tax records in the context of crimes of the seriousness of those which are in issue in the Stewart and Costigan areas of inquiry. That argument is well and truly made out. However, the reservations that we have is that there are insufficient limitations on the ways in which these powers can be exercised in the future. There are insufficient guarantees that the powers will be exercised only in areas where the issues are as open and shut as they appear to be in the Costigan and Stewart royal commissions.

The Opposition moved two amendments in the House of Representatives to communicate our concern about the absence of sufficient safeguards. One of those amendments has now been accepted by the Government-not very gracefully, expeditiously and clearly, it is true, given the odd way in which it has tucked its acceptance of our amendment into another piece of associated legislation rather than the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) which deals with royal commissions. But accept it it has and we are duly grateful for that. That amendment sought to limit the classes of offence in respect of which a royal commissioner could make disclosures to the Attorney-General, and in turn the Attorney-General could make disclosures to the police authorities, to offences which are genuinely serious in nature. The identification of 'seriousness' which seems to be commonly accepted-it is the one which we advanced- is an offence which is punishable by a gaol term of more than six months.

The only comment I make about the Government's acceptance of our amendment moved those terms is that it seems to me to be extraordinarily odd that the Government insisted on using its own terminology, referring not just to offences , punishment for which exceeds six months imprisonment, but to offences punishable for imprisonment for life, as if the expression 'for life' was not covered by and subsumed by the reference to terms of imprisonment exceeding six months. We all know that 'for life' is a flexible term of imprisonment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people have a short life.

—We all know, as Senator Macklin says, that some people have a short life but I would not have thought, on anyone's analysis, that a sentence of life imprisonment could possibly be considered as covering a period of less than six months. Be that as it may, it is essentially a semantic quibble. The real substance of our amendment, which remains unacceptable to the Government, is that which we will be moving formally at the Committee stage, and which I shall now anticipate. It is designed to ensure that, so far as any future royal commission is concerned, the Parliament shall have a voice in determining whether that royal commission should have the powers in question. As this legislation is written at the moment, as Senator Tate put it so cogently, any royal commission that might be established in the future-any investigation which formally satisfies that description, whatever its subject matter-will have power of access to tax records, however inappropriate that might be in the particular case, however much it might amount to the use of a sledge hammer to crack a nut in the context of the area of inquiry in question.

SPEECH.PARA: For these reasons the Opposition proposes to move that these powers shall be capable of being exercised by only those royal commissions which are endorsed, by an affirmative resolution of both Houses of the Parliament, as appropriate to possess powers of access to tax records. Our point is very obvious. Royal commissions are established, and have been over a long time, for all sorts of purposes and reasons-for areas of inquiry as narrow as, for example, a particular local government administration or, on the other hand, as potentially wide and all-embracing as the national security. Issues that one thinks of in that context would include those raised in the Petrov inquiry, which still enjoys considerable notoriety. We do not think it appropriate that a royal commission of any kind, simply by virtue of satisfying that description, should acquire in an open-ended way, these quite enormous and hitherto, in our system of justice, quite unprecendented powers.

We propose a very simple amendment which communicates the proposition that I have outlined. It is one that I suspect would appeal to a good many honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. Of course, the difficulty with which we are confronted in moving such an amendment-which I still propose to do at the Committee stage, although I will not press it to a vote-is that if it were so pressed, if the Government were defeated and if the amendment were inserted, we would be in the most unhappy situation that the Bill would have to sit on the stocks until next August, in the event that the Government was not prepared to bring the House of Representatives back to endorse the amendment in question.

That point was made by Senator Siddons, and even more graphically by Senator Harradine, when he referred to the Government holding a gun at our heads in this respect. The Opposition believes that the House of Representatives should never have got up so early, should not have scuttled for cover, should not have used the first opportunity available to it to retreat from the fire that it was under from the Opposition. In particular, it should not have dispersed to the four winds knowing that important legislation such as this remained to be debated by the Senate-legislation which demanded considerable attention to detail in the interests of the protection of the civil rights and liberties of ordinary Australians. It is a disgrace that the Government, knowing that this legislation was on the stocks, should have chosen to treat the Parliament in this way. The Government should be back here doing its democratic duty in every one of the respects that I have mentioned, and in particular listening to what I am sure the Senate, had it freedom of action, would want to say about the limitations of this legislation.

INTERJECT.PARA: The only other matter I seek to refer to is the Australian Wool Testing Authority, which was referred to by all speakers in the debate. It is quite clear that the Authority, although it is now operating properly, has done so only in the last five years of its 25 years of life. It has now reached a position where it can stand alone without the support of the Australian Wool Corporation which has so far provided the staff and the facilities for its work.
