DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Daw Park Repatriation General Hospital, South Australia

PROCTEXT.PARA: Daw Park Repatriation General Hospital, South Australia
Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise a matter concerning the Daw Park Repatriation General Hospital in South Australia. Had the other House been sitting I would not have had this task tonight because my colleague, Mr Ralph Jacobi, the honourable member for Hawker, would have raised the matter in the other place. I want to put questions to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). I understand that Mr Jacobi might have communicated with him about this problem in recent days. I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that the Repatriation General Hospital at Daw Park has traditionally had to manage at a lower level of staffing than have State hospitals in South Australia. Is it also a fact that, on average, 3.63 hours of nursing care are given to each patient in 24 hours at the RGH whereas the minimum recommended rate is four hours in South Australian government hospitals? I ask him also whether it is a fact that, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, it has been proposed that by July 1982 there be a reduction of 40 staff in all categories at Daw Park Hospital. If implemented, will that proposal exacerbate the already critical staffing situation and, ultimately, result in the closure of services provided to ex-servicemen?

SPEECH.PARA: I further ask the Minister whether he agrees that the amount of medical care required by ex-servicemen who served in the Second World War is likely to increase in the future, not to mention the number of aged veterans who need proper care and attention in the hospital at Daw Park? When talking about aged veterans, I am talking about returned servicemen from World War I.

Further, is it a fact that the nurses at the RGH at Daw Park are currently disadvantaged by wage relativities and that expected community wage movements are certain to increase the salaries of nurses employed elsewhere in the State well beyond the salaries of those employed at the RGH? What action has the Minister taken to restore relativity? Does he also agree that, until relativity and staff levels are restored, not only nurses but also servicemen will be treated as second class citizens compared with their counterparts in State hospitals?

I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that there is widespread discontent and concern amongst staff at the repatriation hospital at Daw Park flowing from the savage cuts in the recommendations of the Lynch committee which proposed a reduction in the staff level at the hospital. As a consequence, it is possible that the standard of care for ex-servicemen will markedly deteriorate and that the staff has unavoidably suffered an increase in its workload because of these recommendations.

I have tried to be as brief as possible tonight. In the light of the matters that I have raised with the Minister and in the light of this appalling indictment of the Government's policy, will the Minister undertake to convene a meeting in Adelaide of staff representatives to enable them to air their grievances and, equally importantly, to ensure implementation of policies that will restore to our ex-servicemen the care to which they are entitled. I apologise for being so brief in my remarks, but I hope that the Minister, if he cannot give me an answer tonight, will read the Hansard report tomorrow. Being the responsible Minister, no doubt he has taken on board what I have said and will be able to give me an answer tonight. In the event that he cannot, I ask him to give me some answers to the questions that I have posed before the Senate rises. I ask him particularly to say to me and to Mr Jacobi, who has asked me to raise this matter, that he will convene a meeting of the concerned staff members at the hospital and have a round table conference with them to try to iron out some of the problems that they will be confronted with as a result of the recommendations of the razor gang.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply -Firstly, I am unable to confirm in detail the numbers and the facts that Senator McLaren has cited, but I make a number of points about the situation. First and foremost, it is true that the Review of Commonwealth Functions recommended a reduction of staff for all departments of the Commonwealth Government. The Department of Veterans' Affairs is in no way exempt from that. The decision in the case of the Department of Veterans' Affairs was a reduction of 2 per cent. That has been well known for some considerable time. That means that over the last 12-month period there has needed to be an implementation of that decision in all areas of the Department's operations. That is being undertaken in such a way as to ensure that services to veterans in particular are maintained at the highest possible level. I say that because we need to recognise that all hospitals, whether Daw Park in Adelaide or any other hospital , take in a substantial number of non-veterans and a further substantial number of non-entitled veterans. This means that there comes from those persons receiving treatment at Daw Park revenue which is not a direct cost upon the budget of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. That means that to be able to maintain the proper level of services to veterans it is possible to change the level of services that we are able to provide to persons who are not veterans or who are non-entitled veterans without necessarily affecting the wellbeing of individual veterans. Honourable senators will recall that the repatriation legislation requires the Repatriation Commission to provide direct care and benefit and to look after the wellbeing of entitled veterans in the first place. I have to reject criticism that the Department is not attending to its duty, in the way Senator McLaren implied during his remarks, in looking after entitled veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLaren raised the question of staff meetings. He may not know but some five or six weeks ago, in Adelaide, I had an interview with officials of both the Hospital Employees Federation of Australia and the Royal Australian Nursing Federation on this particular problem at Daw Park. They made appropriate representations to me. We are still investigating a number of points. I intend to have further discussions with them in the company of the head of the Department of Veterans' Affairs in the not too distant future. That date has not yet been settled as it depends on when the Senate rises.

The further point I make in that regard is that it is not really for the Minister, in circumstances such as these, to become involved in detailed questions of staffing levels, appropriate ratios and so on. Rather, these are matters for the management of individual hospitals. It must be said that conditions in various hospitals vary considerably from unit to unit. It is not always appropriate to apply measurements that might be used in one hospital, with one set of circumstances, to another hospital. I think that is particularly true when comparing State hospitals with repatriation hospitals. However, I take on board the point that Senator McLaren has made and I will further investigate that aspect of the problem. He can rest assured that I will be discussing the matter further with the union representatives in the not too distant future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Based on current 1981-82 personal income tax rates, what amount of tax will be payable by a single person, entitled to the general exemption of $4,195, whose taxable income for 1981-82 is $4,160; $80 per week.
(2) If the answer to question (1) is nil, why is a weekly tax instalment deduction of $1 currently being made from the pay of such a single person earning $80 per week.

(3) Are the weekly tax instalment deductions of a single person earning $90 per week, $1.25 per week in excess of those required to pay the 1981-82 tax on a taxable income of $4,680; if so, does this mean that that particular person is paying tax instalment deductions at the rate of 45.57 cents in the taxable dollar. Is the tax rate approved by Parliament for 1981-82 equal to 32 cents in the dollar for taxable incomes between $4,195 and $17,894; if so, what is the legislative authority for the Commissioner of Taxation to collect weekly tax instalment deductions at rates 42 per cent higher than the income tax rates approved by Parliament.
(4) In how many other cases are the 1981-82 weekly and fortnightly tax instalment deductions at rates higher than the income tax rates approved by Parliament.
(5) What is the purpose of these excess tax instalment deductions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No tax will be payable in 1981-82 by a person whose taxable income is $4, 160.

(2) The prescribed schedules of pay-as-you-earn deductions incorporate loadings designed to permit leave bonuses to be paid generally without deduction of tax instalments and to cover any shortfall in deductions that might otherwise occur where employees receive, in addition to their earnings, small amounts of income that have not been subject to tax instalments. The first of these loadings enables the leave bonus to be paid in most cases without any further deduction of tax instalments at the time of its payment. If the bonus were treated, at the time of payment, as ordinary earnings for tax instalment purposes, the result would often be that tax instalments would be deducted at a rate higher than is appropriate, having regard to the employee's annual earnings. Also, the amounts of weekly income shown in the prescribed schedule cover amounts up to the top of each dollar step in weekly earnings. For example, the instalment shown against weekly earnings of $80 in the schedule of tax instalment deductions covers earnings of $80.00 to $80.99 and is that applicable to weekly earnings of $80.99 . It is for these reasons that weekly tax instalment deductions at the rate of $ 1 are required to be made from weekly earnings of $80 by a person without dependants.

(3) and (4) For a person without dependants earning $90 per week the tax instalments on an annual basis are $65.80 (approximately $1.27 per week) in excess of the 1981-82 tax payable on assessment on a taxable income of $4,680. The rate of tax as enacted for the 1981-82 financial year on taxable incomes of $4,196 to $17,894 is 32 per cent applied to the excess of taxable income over $ 4195. The tax instalments on earnings of $90 per week represent 45.57 per cent of the excess of $4,680 over $4,195. However, as indicated in answer to part (2) , the annual income that corresponds to weekly earnings of $90 is greater by the amount of the leave bonus which is not subjected to tax instalment deductions on payment, and the tax instalments are accordingly calculated on a higher figure. The weekly tax instalments are as prescribed in the Income Tax Regulations. At all levels of earnings, where the taxpayer's circumstances are such that the leave bonus and any income not subject to tax instalments or provisional tax are less than had been allowed for in the schedule, the tax instalments will be higher than the tax payable on assessment. On the other hand, if an employee receives a greater leave bonus or has more other income than is allowed for in the schedules, tax instalments would be insufficient to cover the final tax payable for the financial year.

(5) See (2) above. It should perhaps be added that, notwithstanding these arrangements, many salary and wage earners are required to pay tax on assessment because the tax instalment deductions are insufficient to cover the tax payable on their total taxable income. More than 650,000 debit assessments have issued so far this financial year to salary and wage earners. Any reduction in the rates of instalments would increase the incidence of such debit assessments. I believe that most salary and wage earners prefer to have tax deducted at rates that will ensure refunds rather than be faced with tax bills, however small, on assessment of their returns. Moreover, where an employee's circumstances are such that the instalments payable under the prescribed schedules are likely to exceed considerably the tax payable on assessment, the Commission of Taxation is authorised by section 221D of the Income Tax Assessment Act to vary the instalments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What taxation concessions and exemptions are available to primary producers which are not available to non-primary producers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not practicable to set out all the terms of the various taxation concessions available to primary producers. Nor is it practicable to state in detail how they differ from taxation concessions available to non-primary producers because the taxation laws make special concessions for other industries and occupations, mining, petroleum, afforestation, Australian film making, authors, inventors, provision of travellers' accommodation, et cetera.
I trust the following outline of the taxation concessions available to primary producers will answer the honourable senator's question.
Income Tax-Assessable Income
Insurance recoveries in respect of losses of livestock and trees may be spread over 5 years.
Proceeds of a second wool clip in one year of income may be included in the assessable income of the following year.

Profits arising from the disposal of livestock as a result of the compulsory acquisition of land, the loss or destruction of pastures or fodder by reason of fire, drought or flood, the taking of a lease of land by a State for the purposes of tick eradication or the compulsory destruction of livestock for the purpose of controlling or eradicating certain diseases may be spread over 5 years. By way of alternative to the preceding concession, where livestock is disposed of by reason of the loss or destruction of pastures or fodder by fire, drought or flood or is compulsorily disposed of for the purpose of controlling or eradicating certain diseases, the profits may be excluded from assessable income and applied to reducing the cost of replacement stock acquired during the ensuing 5 years.
Allowable deductions
Depreciation is allowable on fences, dams and other structural improvements on land which is used for the purposes of agriculture or pastoral pursuits.
Depreciation on structural improvements used for the storage of hay, grain or fodder acquired or constructed after 21 August 1979 is allowable over 5 years.
Depreciation on new items of plant and equipment used wholly for primary production purposes acquired or constructed after 30 September 1980 is allowable over 5 years.
The cost of extending a telephone line to land used for primary production is deductible over 10 years.
Certain specified capital expenditures may be deducted over 10 years, for example:
destruction and removal of timber, scrub or undergrowth indigenous to the land;
preparation of the land for agriculture;
ploughing and grassing the land for grazing purposes;
draining of swamp or low-lying lands;
preventing or combating flooding on the land.

Expenditure incurred on and after 14 April 1980 on the acquisition, construction or installation of plant or structural improvements, or extensions thereto, for the purpose of conserving or conveying water for use on the land is an allowable deduction.

Expenditure incurred before 1 July 1984 on the construction of stock yards of sub-divisional fences where the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry has certified their construction assists in the eradication or control of brucelilosis or tuberculosis may be an allowable deduction.
Expenditure incurred on or after 1 October 1980 on specified works for soil conservation is an allowable deduction.
An investment allowance deduction is available on certain structural improvements used in a business of primary production.
A primary producer is not restricted by the 7 years limitation on the recoupment of prior year losses that applies to non-primary producers.
Income Equalisation Deposits

Due to the wide fluctuations which may occur in their incomes from one year to the next, primary producers are encouraged to participate in the income equalisation deposits scheme. Deposits into the scheme are allowable deductions while the proceeds received on withdrawal of deposits for which income tax deductions have previously been allowed are to be included in assessable income of the primary producer in the year of withdrawal.
Averaging of Income

A special averaging rebate may be subtracted from ordinary tax payable where a primary producer's taxable income exceeds the average of the taxable incomes for a period of 5 years. Where the average income exceeds the taxable income, the rebate does not apply and tax is payable at ordinary rates. The rebate which is allowable in any year will depend on the extent of primary production and other income derived in the year.
Sales Tax

Generally speaking goods for use in a business of primary production, other than road vehicles of the kind ordinarily used for the transport of persons or the delivery of goods, are exempt from sales tax. The types of goods to which exemption applies are set out in detail in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax ( Exemptions and Classifications) Act.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Investigations have revealed that PCB substances may be present in small quantities in some of the electronic and radiocommunications equipment owned by the Department. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Internal Revenue Service of the United States of America accept religious tithes and offerings as deductible expenditure for the purposes of taxation; if so, will the Treasurer give consideration to introducing this item as a deduction available to Australian taxpayers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is my understanding that contributions to a wide range of charitable, religious and educational organisations qualify for deduction under United States taxation law, subject to certain generally applicable deduction limits.

Existing provisions of the Australian income tax law permit deductions for gifts to public funds established and maintained exclusively for the purpose of providing religious instruction in government schools. Gifts towards school building funds also qualify for deduction.

Proposals to grant deductions for gifts generally for religious purposes have been considered on a number of occasions by successive Governments. The significant revenue cost has no doubt been a factor in the rejection of those proposals. The matter has, however, been listed again for consideration in the context of the forthcoming Budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action is to be taken to implement the report of the Task Force on Government Information.
(2) What action is to be taken to better serve people identified in the report as missing out on welfare benefits because of lack of information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I announced on 3 February 1982 that the Government, having regard to the report of the Task Force on Departmental Information, was taking measures to improve the quality and effectiveness of departmental information programs. The Department of Administrative Services is to develop the capacity to provide the necessary co-ordination and expert advice and is in the process of establishing an information co-ordination group which has, as a prime objective, the upgrading of departmental information activities along the lines recommended in the Task Force report.

(2) One of the specific objectives to be followed in the review and co- ordination of departmental information programs will be to ensure that disadvantaged members of the community are informed about rights, obligations and administrative procedures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the Aboriginal artists whose works have been reproduced in the 1982 Australian Government Publishing Service calendar received any compensation for their publication.
(2) Did the collectors or present owners of the bark paintings receive any reward to permit publication in the 1982 calendar.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Reproduction of the 13 Aboriginal bark paintings used in the Australian Information Service (AIS) 1982 calendar, which is published by the Australian Government Publishing Service, was arranged through the Aboriginal Artists Agency, a non-profit company funded by the Commonwealth Government to represent Aboriginal artists in copyright matters. The agency determined that a reproduction fee of $100 should be paid to each artist. AIS paid these fees through the agency.

(2) The bark paintings used in the calendar are from the National Ethnographic Collection held at the Australian Institute of Anatomy, Canberra. The Institute of Anatomy sought no compensation for their use, nor did the two collectors who are still alive, Dr H. Groger-Wurm and Dr K. Kupka.

ANSWER.PARA: Although my Department has issued no specific instruction to staff that they are not permitted to smoke while interviewing clients, some local supervisors have insisted upon such a prohibition whilst others in offices having public contact have counselled staff to be discreet and take note of client/ applicant attitudes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it the case that service pensions are paid fortnightly if payment is by cheque, but if payment is made directly into a bank, building society or other account, the pension is credited to the account at twelve-weekly intervals; if so, will the Minister take steps to rectify this anomaly and have payments of service pensions paid into accounts fortnightly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: All repatriation pensioners have the option to have pensions paid fortnightly by cheque or by direct deposit to an account at a bank, building society or credit union every twelve weeks. TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1658), Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: What action is the Government proposing to take to prevent the imposition of sugar import quotas by the United States of America? Is he aware of strong speculation that these quotas will be announced within a few days? Is he also aware of recent criticism by the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board of political pressure being exerted by the United States to displace Australian wheat exports to some of our traditional customers? Does the Minister believe that the announcement of sugar quotas might be delayed by the United States until the departure from Australia of the American Vice-President, Mr Bush? In view of this, will the Government be taking up vigorously the matter of sugar and wheat exports with Mr Bush during his visit to Australia which begins tonight?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In mid-April the Government became aware that the United States Government had under consideration the possibility of taking further protective measures on sugar imports and that there was a proposal to discriminate, in the application of these measures, in a way which would have disadvantaged our sugar industry.
The Government immediately made clear to the United States Government our deep concerns about the proposal.

As indicated in my reply to a recent question without notice (House of Representatives Hansard, page 1848 of 27 April), I wrote to the United States Special Trade Representative, Mr Brock, emphasising that the allocation of import quotas among supplying countries on a discriminatory basis to favour those suppliers within the United States' own geographic region would be unacceptable to Australia. Australian officials subsequently made repeated representations to senior US officials both in Canberra and in Washington. The Prime Minister and I also took the opportunity to emphasise Australia's views during discussions which were held in Canberra at the end of last month with US Vice-President, Mr Bush.

Import quotas were proclaimed by President Reagan on 6 May to take effect on 11 May and to be applied non discriminatorily and on the basis of suppliers' recent historical trade performance in the US sugar market. While I could not possibly express satisfaction with any country's decision to introduce restrictions on imports of Australia's sugar, I am encouraged by the evident willingness of the United States to take careful account of Australia's concerns and views on this important bilateral trade matter.

I am now pressing the United States to reduce the current tax on sugar imports , imposed before quotas were introduced. If the United States can be persuaded to relax the current tax of approximately $US80 per tonne, there will be a considerable lift in returns for Australian sugar exporters in the United States market.

As to wheat matters, I am aware of the concern of the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board regarding the United States Administration's aggressive approach to wheat exports. Australia's concern is that in a period of increasing global wheat stocks, 'beggar thy neighbour' marketing practices will be damaging to all wheat exporters. At a recent wheat exporters' meeting in Ottawa, Australia therefore urged other exporting countries, in particular the EEC and the USA, to exercise moderation with regard to their wheat export policies.
